COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  L.D. 390  1

REPORT A  3 
APPROPRIATIONS AND FINANCIAL AFFAIRS  4 
Reproduced and distributed under the direction of the Clerk of the House.  5 
STATE OF MAINE  6 
HOUSE OF REPRESENTAT IVES  7 
128TH LEGISLATURE  8 
FIRST REGULAR SESSIO N 9 
COMMITTEE A MENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390, Bill, “An Act Making 10 
Unified Appropriations and Allocations for the Expenditures of State Government, 11 
General Fund and Other Funds and Changing Certain Provisions of the Law Necessary to 12 
the Proper Operations of State Go vernment for the Fiscal Years Ending June 30, 2018 13 
and June 30, 2019”  14 
Amend the bill by striking out everything after the title and inserting the following:  15 
'Emergency preamble. Whereas, acts and resolves of the Legislature do not 16 
become effective until 90  days after adjournment unless enacted as emergencies; and  17 
Whereas, the 90 -day period may not terminate until after the beginning of the next 18 
fiscal year; and  19 
Whereas, certain obligations and expenses incident to the operation of state 20 
departments and inst itutions will become due and payable immediately; and  21 
Whereas, in the judgment of the Legislature, these facts create an emergency within 22 
the meaning of the Constitution of Maine and require the following legislation as 23 
immediately necessary for the preser vation of the public peace, health and safety; now, 24 
therefore,  25 
Be it enacted by the People of the State of Maine as follows:  26 
PART A  27 
Sec. A -1.  Appropriations and allocations.  The following appropriations and 28 
allocations are made.  29 
ADMINISTRATIVE AND FINANC IAL SERVICES, DEPARTMENT OF  30

Administration - Human Resources 0038  6 
Initiative: Eliminates one vacant Plumber II position and one vacant Boiler Engineer 7 
position from the Building and Grounds Opera tions program, General Fund. This 8 
initiative also transfers one vacant Space Management Specialist position and one vacant 9 
High Voltage Electrician position from the Buildings and Grounds Operations program to 10 
the Administration - Human Resources program w ithin the same fund and reorganizes the 11 
High Voltage Electrician position to a Public Service Manager II position and the Space 12 
Management Specialist position to a Public Service Manager III position.  13 
 
 14 
 15 
 16 
 17 
 18 
 
Administration - Human Resources 0038  19 
Initiative: Transfers one Public Service Coordinator I position from the Public 20 
Improvements - Planning/Construc tion - Administration program to the Administration - 21 
Human Resources program within the same fund to realign department resources to areas 22 
of greatest need. The employee retains all rights as a classified employee, as well as all 23 
accrued fringe benefits, including but not limited to vacation and sick leave, health and 24 
life insurances and retirement benefits.  25 
 
 26 
 27 
 28 
 29 
 
 30

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  Central Services - Purchases 0004  1 
Initiative: Transfers one Public Service Manager II position from the Division of 2 
Purchases, Postal, Printing and Supply Fund, to the Central Services - Purchases program, 3 
General Fund and transfers one Public Service Manager I position from the Central 4 
Services - Purchases program, General Fund, to the Division of Purchases program, 5 
Postal, Printing and Supply Fund.   Also eliminates one vacant Buyer II po sition in the 6 
Division of Purchases program, General Fund.  7

 10 
 11

Financial and Personnel Services - Division of 0713  20 
Initiative: Transfers and reallocates the cost of 18 Accounting Assistant Technician 21 
positions and 5 Clerk IV positions from the Department of Health and Human Services, 22 
Office of the Commissioner District Operations program, 64% General Fund and 36% 23 
Other Special Revenue Funds ,  to the Department of Administrative and Financial 24 
Services, Division of Financial and Personnel Services program, 100% Financial and 25 
Personnel Services Fund, and increases the hours of one Accounting Assistant Technician 26 
position from  52 hours to 80 ho urs biweekly.  Also increases associated All Other 27 
expenditures and increases Service Center billing to fund the positions.  Employees will 28 
retain all rights as classified employees, as well as all accrued fringe benefits, including 29 
but not limited to vaca tion and sick leave, health and life insurances and retirement 30 
benefits.  31

Education in Unorganized Territory 0220  21 
Initiative: Transfers one Teacher Aide position from the Federal Expen ditures Fund to the 22 
General Fund within the same program. Transfers and reallocates the cost of one Teacher 23 
MS position from 100% General Fund to 50% Federal Expenditures Fund and 50% 24

Child Support 0100  29 
Initiative: Transfers and reallocates 93 positions from 33.3 % General Fund and 66.7% 30 
Federal Expenditures Fund to 34% General Fund and 66% Federal Expenditures Fund 31 
within the same program and adjusts All Other related to STA -CAP charges.  Also 32 
transfers and reallocates 86 positions from 33.3% Other Special Revenue  Funds and 33 
66.7% Federal Expenditures Fund to 34% Other Special Revenue Funds and 66% Federal 34 
Expenditures Fund within the same program and adjusts All Other related to STA -CAP 35 
charges to be in line with federal match requirements. Position detail is on fi le in the 36 
Bureau of the Budget.  37

Initiative: Transfers one Public Service Manager I position from the Department of 4 
Administrative and Financial Services, Inform ation Services program, Office of 5 
Information Services Fund to the Department of Professional and Financial Regulation, 6

Revenue Funds and transfers All Other to Personal  Services to fund the position. The 8 
employee retains all rights as a classified employee as well as all accrued fringe benefits, 9 
including but not limited to vacation and sick leave, health and life insurances, and 10 
retirement benefits.  11

PART C  11 
Sec. C -1.  20-A MRSA §1051, sub -§6, ¶D is enacted to read:  12 
D.  A group of school administrative units that has an interlocal agreement pursuant 13 
to Title 30 -A, chapter 115 to establish a regional education service  agency to jointly 14 
purchase the services of a superintendent may elect the superintendent in the manner 15 
prescribed in the interlocal agreement.  16 
Sec. C -2.  20-A MRSA §4722 -A, sub -§4, as amended by PL 2015, c. 489, §2, is 17 
repealed.  18 
Sec. C -3.  20-A MRSA §5806 , sub -§2, as repealed and replaced by PL 2013, c. 19 
497, §1, is amended to read:  20 
2.  Maximum allowable tuition.   The maximum allowable tuition charged to a 21 
school administrative unit by a private school is the rate established under subsection 1 or 22 
the state  average per public secondary student cost as adjusted, whichever is lower, plus 23 
an insured value factor.  The insured value factor is computed by dividing 5% of the 24 
insured value of school buildings and equipment by the average number of pupils 25 
enrolled i n the school on October 1st and April 1st of the year immediately before the 26 
school year for which the tuition charge is computed.  From school year 2009 -2010 to 27 
school year 2013 -2014, a school administrative unit is not required to pay an insured 28 
value fa ctor greater than 5% of the school's tuition rate or $500 per student, whichever is 29 
less, unless the legislative body of the school administrative unit votes to authorize its 30 
school board to pay a higher insured value factor that is no greater than 10% of the 31 
school’s tuition rate per student.  For the 2014 -2015 school year, a school administrative 32 
unit is not required to pay an insured value factor greater than 6% of the school's tuition 33 
rate per student, unless the legislative body of the school administr ative unit votes to 34 
authorize its school board to pay a higher insured value factor that is no greater than 10% 35 
of the school's tuition rate per student.  Beginning in the 2015 -2016 school year, a school 36 
administrative unit is not required to pay an insure d value factor greater than the amount 37 
of the prior school year's insured value factor adjusted by a percentage equal to the 38 
percentage change in the state share percentage of the total cost of funding public 39 
education in the prior school year as determine d by section 15671, subsection 7, 40 SECTION TOTALS  2017 -18 2018 -19 
   
GENERAL FUND  $0 $0

MANAGEMENT FUND  $0 $0

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 592 - 128LR 2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  paragraph C D as compared to the applicable percentage for the current school year.  In 1 
no case may the insured value factor be less than 6% or greater than 10% of the school's 2 
tuition rate per student, unless the legislat ive body of the school administrative unit votes 3 
to authorize its school board to pay an insured value factor that exceeds the amount 4 
otherwise permitted by this subsection by no more than 5% of the school's tuition rate per 5 
student.  For the 2013 -2014 sch ool year only, the maximum allowable tuition charged to 6 
a school administrative unit by a private school that participates in the Maine Public 7 
Employees Retirement System must be increased above the amount otherwise permitted 8 
under this section by an amoun t equal to the calculated normal cost of teacher retirement 9 
for that school divided by the number of enrolled students as of October 1, 2012.  10 
Sec. C -4.  20-A MRSA §6955 is enacted to read:  11 
§6955.  Repeal  12 
This chapter is repealed July 1, 2019.  13 
Sec. C -5.  20-A MRSA §15671, first ¶, as enacted by PL 2001, c. 660, §1, is 14 
amended to read:  15 
Essential programs and services are those educational resources that are identified in 16 
this chapter necessary to ensure the opportunity  for all students to meet the standards i n 17 
the 8 content standard subject areas and goals  of the system of learning results established 18 
in chapter 222.  In order to achieve this system of learning results, school funding based 19 
on essential programs and services must be available in all schools on  an equitable basis.  20 
Essential programs and services utilize resources including federal funds  that are 21 
currently provided or could be adapted to implement a system of learning results, as well 22 
as additional resources including federal funds  that are also  needed to ensure that these 23 
programs and services are available to all students.  These essential programs and 24 
services must provide the basis for the system of school funding no later than 2007 -08.  25 
School funding must be adequate to fully provide for al l of the staffing and other material 26 
resource needs of the essential programs and services identified by the Legislature.  27 
Sec. C -6.  20-A MRSA §15671, sub -§1, as amended by PL 2015, c. 267, Pt. L, 28 
§10, is further amended to read:  29 
1.  State and local partne rship.   The State and each local school administrative unit 30 
are jointly responsible for contributing to the cost of the components of essential 31 
programs and services described in this chapter.  Except as otherwise provided in this 32 
subsection, for each fisc al year, the total cost of the components of essential programs 33 
and services may not exceed the prior fiscal year's costs multiplied by one plus the 34 
average personal income growth rate as defined in Title 5, section 1665, subsection 1.  35 
The Legislature, by  an affirmative vote of each House, may exceed the limitations on 36 
increases in the total cost of the components of essential programs and services provided 37 
in this subsection, as long as that vote is taken upon legislation stating that it is the 38 
Legislatur e's intent to override the limitation for that fiscal year.  The state contribution to 39 
the cost of the components of essential programs and services , exclusive of federal funds 40 
that are provided and accounted for in the cost of the components of essential programs 41 
and services,  must be made in accordance with this subsection:  42 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 593 - 128LR2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  A.  The level of the state share of funding attributable to the cost of the components 1 
of essential programs and services must be at least 50% of eligible state and local 2 
General Fund education costs statewide, no later than fiscal year 2006 -07; and  3 
B.  By fiscal year 2008 -09 the state share of the total cost of funding public education 4 
from kindergarten to grade 12, as described by essential programs and services, must 5 
be 55%.  Beginni ng in fiscal year 2005 -06 and in each fiscal year until fiscal year 6 
2008 -09, the state share of essential programs and services described costs must 7 
increase toward the 55% level required in fiscal year 2008 -09. 8 
Beginning in fiscal year 2005 -06 and in each  fiscal year thereafter, the commissioner 9 
shall use the funding level determined in accordance with this section as the basis for a 10 
recommended funding level for the state share of the cost of the components of essential 11 
programs and services.  12 
Sec. C -7.  20-A MRSA §15671, sub -§6, as amended by PL 2005, c. 519, Pt. LL, 13 
§1, is further amended to read:  14 
6.  Targeted funds.   Funds for technology, implementation of a standards -based 15 
system and the costs of additional investments in educating children in kindergar ten to 16 
grade 2 as described in section 15681 must be provided as targeted allocations.  School 17 
administrative units shall submit a plan for the use of these funds and receive funding 18 
based on approval of the plan by the commissioner.  State funds for exten ded learning 19 
provided above the basic economically disadvantaged student adjustment in section 20 
15675, subsection 2 must also be provided as targeted allocations and restricted to 21 
approved programs that benefit economically disadvantaged students.  22 
Sec. C -8.  20-A MRSA §15671, sub -§7, ¶A, as amended by PL 2013, c. 368, Pt. 23 
C, §6, is further amended to read:  24 
A.  The base total calculated pursuant to section 15683, subsection 2 is subject to the 25 
following annual targets.  26

Sec. C -14.  20-A MRSA §15671 -A, sub -§5, as amended by PL 2005, c. 519, Pt. 16 
AAAA, §2, is further amended to read:  17 
5.  Exceeding maximum state and loc al spending target.   If the sum of a school 18 
administrative unit's required local contribution determined pursuant to section 15688, 19 
subsection 3 -A plus the state contribution as calculated pursuant to section 15688, 20 
subsection 3 -A, paragraph D , plus any st ate funds resulting from a transition adjustment 21 
pursuant to section 15686,  plus any additional local amount proposed to be raised 22 
pursuant to section 15690, subsection 3 exceeds the school administrative unit's 23 
maximum state and local spending target esta blished pursuant to subsection 4, the 24 
following provisions govern approval of that additional amount.  25 
A.  The article approving the additional amount must conform to the requirements of 26 
section 15690, subsection 3, paragraph B.  Notwithstanding section 130 4, subsection 27 
6; section 1701, subsection 7; Title 30 -A, section 2528, subsection 5, or any other 28 
provision of law, municipal charter provision or ordinance, voter approval of the 29 
article, whether in town meeting, district meeting or other voting process e stablished 30 
by law, municipal charter or ordinance, including, but not limited to, any vote on the 31 
article initiated by voter petition, must be by referendum or written ballot.  32 
B.  In a municipality where the responsibility for final adoption of the school budget 33 
is vested by the municipal charter in a council, this paragraph applies, except that the 34 
petition and referendum provisions apply only if the municipal charter does not 35 
otherwise provide for or prohibit a petition and referendum process with respect  to 36 
the matters described in this paragraph.  37 
(1)  A majority of the entire membership of the school board or committee must 38 
approve the additional amount in a regular budget meeting.  39 
(2)  An article approving the additional amount must conform to the requi rements 40 
of section 15690, subsection 3, paragraph B and be approved by a majority of the 41 
entire membership of the council in a vote taken in accordance with section 42 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 597 - 128LR2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  15690, subsection 5 or, if the council votes not to approve the article, by a 1 
majority of v oters voting in a referendum called pursuant to subparagraph (4).  2 
(3)  If an article is approved by the council pursuant to subparagraph (2), the 3 
voters may petition for a referendum vote on the same article in accordance with 4 
subparagraph (4).  If a petit ion is filed in accordance with subparagraph (4), the 5 
vote of the council is suspended pending the outcome of the referendum vote.  6 
Upon approval of the article by a majority of the voters voting in that 7 
referendum, the article takes effect.  If the articl e is not approved by a majority of 8 
the voters voting in that referendum, the article does not take effect.  Subsequent 9 
to the vote, the school committee or board may again propose an additional 10 
amount, subject to the requirements of this section.  11 
(4)  If a  written petition, signed by at least 10% of the number of voters voting in 12 
the last gubernatorial election in the municipality, requesting a vote on the 13 
additional amount is submitted to the municipal officers within 30 days of the 14 
council's vote pursuant  to subparagraph (2), the article voted on by the council 15 
must be submitted to the legal voters in the next regular election or a special 16 
election called for the purpose.  The election must be held within 45 days of the 17 
submission of the petition.  The ele ction must be called, advertised and conducted 18 
according to the law relating to municipal elections, except that the registrar of 19 
voters is not required to prepare or the clerk to post a new list of voters and 20 
absentee ballots must be prepared and made ava ilable at least 14 days prior to the 21 
date of the referendum.  For the purpose of registration of voters, the registrar of 22 
voters must be in session the secular day preceding the election.  The voters shall 23 
indicate by a cross or check mark placed against t he word "Yes" or "No" their 24 
opinion on the article.  The results must be declared by the municipal officers and 25 
entered upon the municipal records.  26

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §15686 -A.  Review of essential prog rams and services components  1 
1.  Components to be reviewed beginning in fiscal year 2017 -18.  Beginning in 2 
fiscal year 2006 -07 2017 -18, and at least every 3 years thereafter, the commissioner, 3 
using information provided by a statewide education policy rese arch institute, shall 4 
review the essential programs and services student -to-staff ratios, salary and benefits 5 
matrices, transportation,  small schools adjustments, labor markets and gifted and talented 6 
components and components related to implementation of proficiency -based reporting 7 
and graduation requirements  under this chapter and shall submit to the joint standing 8 
committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over education matters any 9 
recommended changes for legislative action.  10 
2.  Components to be r eviewed beginning in fiscal year 2018 -19.  Beginning in 11 
fiscal year 2007 -08 2018 -19, and at least every 3 years thereafter, the commissioner, 12 
using information provided by a statewide education policy research institute, shall 13 
review the essential programs  and services career and technical education, special 14 
education, specialized student populations, system administration and operations and 15 
maintenance components under this chapter and shall submit to the joint standing 16 
committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over education matters any 17 
recommended changes for legislative action.  18 
3.  Components to be reviewed beginning in fiscal year 2019 -20.  Beginning in 19 
fiscal year 2008 -09 2019 -20, and at least every 3 years thereafter, the commissioner, 20 
using in formation provided by a statewide education policy research institute, shall 21 
review the essential programs and services professional development, student assessment, 22 
technology, transportation,  leadership support, cocurricular and extra -curricular activiti es, 23 
supplies and equipment and, beginning in fiscal year 2016 -17, charter school  components 24 
under this chapter and shall submit to the joint standing committee of the Legislature 25 
having jurisdiction over education matters any recommended changes for legisl ative 26 
action.  27 
4.  Components to be reviewed beginning in fiscal year 2017 -18.  Beginning in 28 
fiscal year 2017 -18, and at least every 3 years thereafter, the commissioner, using 29 
information provided by a statewide education policy research institute, shall r eview the 30 
essential programs and services components under this chapter related to implementation 31 
of proficiency -based reporting and graduation requirements and shall submit to the joint 32 
standing committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over educat ion matters any 33 
recommended legislative changes.  34 
The commissioner may adjust the schedule by replacing one component in one year 35 
with another component in another year if information on a specific component is needed 36 
in an earlier time frame.  This replace ment may not result in a component's being 37 
reviewed beyond a 4 -year period. The commissioner may include a review of one or 38 
more of the components from sections 15688 -A, 15689 and 15689 -A to the schedule in 39 
addition to the components listed in this section . 40

Sec. C -43.  20-A MRSA §15689, sub -§§14 and 15 are enacted to read:  21 
14.  MaineCare seed for school administrative units.  The commissioner may 22 
deduct from a school administrative unit's state subsidy and pay on behalf o f the school 23 
administrative unit allowable school -based costs that represent the school administrative 24 
unit's portion of MaineCare payments. A transfer of payment by the department to the 25 
Department of Health and Human Services must be made pursuant to a s chedule agreed 26 
upon by the Department of Health and Human Services and the department and in a 27 
manner that remains in compliance with federal intergovernmental transfer requirements. 28

the Department of Health and Human Services shall provide the detailed payment 30 
information to the department. The department shall make this information available and 31 
apply the adjustment to the appropriate school administrative units with in 30 days of 32 
receipt of the detailed payment information from the Department of Health and Human 33 
Services.  34 
15.  Special education budgetary hardship adjustment.  Beginning in fiscal year 35 
2018 -19, the following provisions apply to adjustments for special e ducation budgetary 36 
hardships.  37

petitions the commissioner and demonstrates that the unexpected education costs of 39 
placement of a student in a special education program will caus e a budgetary 40 
hardship, the commissioner may provide to the unit an amount not to exceed the 41 
allowable costs of the placement less 3 times the statewide special education EPS 42 
per-pupil rate for in -district placements or less 4 times the statewide special e ducation 43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 607 - 128LR2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  EPS per -pupil rate for out -of-district placements. The allowable costs are those 1 
special education costs described in section 15672, subsection 30 -A, paragraphs A 2 
and B.  3 
B.  The commissioner shall determine that a school administrative unit is eli gible for 4 
an adjustment under paragraph A if:  5 
(1)  The student's placement is a result of an appeal approved by the 6 
commissioner pursuant to section 5205, subsection 6 or the student became the 7 
fiscal responsibility of the school administrative unit after the passage of that 8 
unit's budget for the current fiscal year; and  9 
(2)  The school administrative unit's unexpected allowable costs result in a 5% or 10 
more increase in the percentage of the unit's special education budget category to 11 
the unit's total budget  excluding the debt service budget category.  12 
C.  The funds for adjustments under paragraph A are limited to the amount 13 
appropriated by the Legislature for that purpose, and any unexpended balance from 14 
another program's appropriated amounts under this chapt er may be applied by the 15 
commissioner toward the adjustments.  16 
D.  A school administrative unit may expend the funds from the adjustment under 17 
paragraph A without seeking approval by the unit's legislative body.  18

amended to read:  21 
§15689 -A.  Authorization of payment of targeted education funds  22 
1.  Payment of state agency client costs.   State agency clie nt costs are payable 23 
pursuant to this subsection.  As used in this subsection, "state agency client" has the same 24 
meaning as defined in section 1, subsection 34 -A. 25 
A.  The commissioner shall approve special education costs and supportive services, 26 
includin g transportation, for all state agency clients placed in residential placements 27 
by an authorized agent of a state agency.  28 
B.  Special education costs authorized by this subsection for state agency clients must 29 
be paid by the department in the allocation ye ar at 100% of actual costs.  30 
C.  The commissioner shall pay only approved special education costs and supportive 31 
services, including transportation, authorized by this subsection for state agency 32 
clients and may not allocate for those special education cost s and supportive services, 33 
including transportation, incurred by the school administrative unit for state agency 34 
clients in the base years starting July 1, 1985, and every base year thereafter.  35 
D.  Transportation costs for state agency clients, when provid ed in accordance with 36 
rules established by the commissioner under section 7204, must be paid by the 37 
department in the allocation year at 100% of actual costs.  38

schools for educat ion institutional residents within the limits of the allocation made 40 
under this section.  41

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  Sec. C -50.  Authorization of payments.  If the State's continued obligation for 1 
any individual component contained in those sections of this Part that set the total cost of 2 
funding public education from kindergarten to grade 12 and the local and state 3 
contributions for that purpose exceeds the level of funding provided for that component,  4 
any unexpended balances occurring in other programs may be applied to avoid proration 5 
of payments for any individual component. Any unexpended balances from this Part may 6 
not lapse but must be carried forward for the same purpose.  7 
Sec. C -51.  Limit of Sta te's obligation.  Those sections of this Part that set the 8 
total cost of funding public education from kindergarten to grade 12 and the local and 9 
state contributions for that purpose may not be construed to require the State to provide 10 
payments that exceed  the appropriation of funds for general purpose aid for local schools 11 
for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2017 and ending June 30, 2018.  12 
Sec. C -52.  Review of funding models.  For fiscal year 2018 -19, the 13 
Commissioner of Education, using information prov ided by a statewide education policy 14 
research institute, shall review the funding models for gifted and talented education and 15 
the miscellaneous allocations under the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 20 -A, section 16 
15689 -A for Jobs for Maine's Graduates, the M aine School of Science and Mathematics, 17 
the Maine Educational Center for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing and the Governor Baxter 18 
School for the Deaf, the Center of Excellence for At -risk Students, the Maine School for 19 
Marine Science, Technology, Transportatio n and Engineering, community schools, 20 
courses for credit at eligible postsecondary institutions and comprehensive early college 21 
programs and make recommendations for providing allocations for these programs within 22 
the adjustments and operating allocations of the essential programs and services funding 23 
model to ensure equity of opportunity and shall submit by January 15, 2018 to the Joint 24 
Standing Committee on Education and Cultural Affairs any recommended legislative 25 
changes.  26 
For fiscal year 2020 -21, using information provided by a statewide education policy 27 
research institute, the commissioner shall also review the per -pupil allocation for system 28 
administration for adequacy and equity in comparison to actual system administration 29 
expenditures of school admi nistrative units with enrollments of over 2,500 students and 30 
shall submit to the joint standing committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over 31 
education matters prior to January 15, 2022 any recommended changes to laws relating to 32 
the allocation.  33 
Sec. C-53.  Effective dates.  The following sections of this Part have the following 34 
effective dates.  35 
1.  That section of this Part that amends the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 20 -A, 36 
section 15683 -B, subsection 3 takes effect July 1, 2017.  37 
2.  That section of this Part that repeals Title 20 -A, section 4722 -A, subsection 4.  38 
3.  That section of this Part that amends Title 20 -A, section 15681 -A, subsection 2 39 
takes effect July 1, 2018.  40

Sec. N -1.  5 MRSA §1710, as enacted by PL 1995, c. 368, Pt. J, §1, is amended to 20 
read:  21 
§1710.  Consensus Economic Forecasting Commission; membership  22 
The Consensus Economic Forecasting Commission established by Title 5, section 23 
12004 -I, subsection 29 -B, to provide the Governor, the Legislature and the Revenue 24 
Forecasting Committee with analyses, findings and recommendations representing state 25 
economic assu mptions relevant to revenue forecasting, and referred to in this chapter as 26 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 620 - 128LR 2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  the "commission," consists of 5 members appointed as follows:  two members appointed 1 
by the Governor; one member recommended for appointment to the Governor by the 2 
President of the  Senate; one member recommended for appointment to the Governor by 3 
the Speaker of the House of Representatives; and one member appointed by the other 4 
members of the commission. One of the 5 members must be selected by a majority vote 5 
of the committee membe rs to serve as the chair of the commission.  Commission 6 
members must be appointed within 15 days of the effective date of this section and serve 7 
until January 1997.   The commission members recommended for appointment to the 8 
Governor by the President of the  Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives 9 
and one of the members appointed by the Governor must be appointed in January 2019 10 
and serve a 2 -year term.  The 2nd member appointed by the Governor and the member 11 
appointed by the other members of t he commission must be appointed in January 2019 12 
and serve a one -year term.   Thereafter, the all commission members are appointed in 13 
January of odd -numbered years  to 2-year terms .  A member may not be a Legislator or an 14 
employee of the Executive Department,  the Legislature or the Judicial Department.  Each 15 
commission member must have professional credentials and demonstrated expertise in 16 
economic forecasting.  17 
All members are appointed for terms to coincide with the legislative biennium.   18 
Vacancies must be fi lled in the same manner as the original appointments for the balance 19 
of the unexpired term, except as otherwise provided in this section.  20 
If one or more positions on the commission remains unfilled on the 16th day after the 21 
effective date of this section o r the expeditious filling of a vacancy is required to enable 22 
the commission to perform its duties in an efficient and timely manner, the Governor 23 
shall make those appointments at such times and in such a manner as the Governor 24 
determines necessary.  25 
Sec. N -2.  5 MRSA §1710 -A, as amended by PL 2007, c. 539, Pt. Q, §1, is further 26 
amended to read:  27 
§1710 -A.  Duties of commission  28 
1.  Duties.  The Consensus Economic Forecasting Commission shall develop 5-year 29 
and 10 -year macroeconomic secular trend forecasts and o ne-year, 2 -year and 4 -year 30 
economic forecasts  for the current fiscal biennium and the next 2 fiscal biennia . 31 
2.  Economic assumptions.  The commission shall submit recommendations for state 32 
economic assumptions for the next fiscal biennium and analyze econ omic assumptions 33 
for the current fiscal biennium, which must be approved by a majority of the commission 34 
members.   No later than November 1st of each even -numbered year and April 1st of each 35 
odd-numbered year , the commission shall submit to the Governor, t he Legislative 36 
Council, the Revenue Forecasting Committee and the joint standing committee of the 37 
Legislature having jurisdiction over appropriations and financial affairs a report that 38 
presents the analyses, findings and recommendations for state economic  assumptions  for 39 
the next 2 fiscal biennia and analyze  economic assumptions related to revenue forecasting 40 
for the next  for the current  fiscal biennium , which must be approved by a majority of the 41 
commission members .  In its report, the commission shall fu lly describe the methodology 42 
employed in reaching its recommendations.  43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 621 - 128LR2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  3.  Current biennium adjustments.  No later than April 1st and  November 1st of 1 
each odd -numbered year and no later than February 1st and November 1st  of each 2 
even -numbered year the comm ission shall submit to the Governor, the Legislative 3 
Council, the Revenue Forecasting Committee and the joint standing committee of the 4 
Legislature having jurisdiction over appropriations and financial affairs a report that 5 
presents the commission's findin gs and recommendations for adjustments to the 6 
economic assumptions for the current fiscal biennium  all forecast years .  In each report 7 
the commission shall fully describe the methodology employed in reaching its 8 
recommendations.  9

PART O  21 
Sec. O -1.  5 MRSA §1725 -A, as amended by PL 1991, c. 780, Pt. Y, §51, is 22 
further amended to read:  23 
§1725 -A.  Risk management  24 
1.  Creation and authority.   The Department of Administrative and Financial 25 
Services is designate d as the agency through which this chapter is administered.  The 26 
Director of the Bureau of General Services, in this chapter called the "director,"  State 27 
Controller  is empowered with such authority as necessary to carry out the purposes of this 28 
chapter.  29 
Risk management responsibilities are under the supervision and administrative control of 30 
the Director of the Bureau of General Services  State Controller . 31 
2.  State Controller.   The commissioner shall appoint  direct  the Director of the 32 
Bureau of General Servi ces, in this chapter called the "director,"  State Controller  to 33 
administer the State's policy on insurance management, as developed through the 34 
authority of this chapter.  The director  State Controller  or the director's  State Controller's  35 
designee must be knowledgeable of insurance practices and principles and must be 36 
qualified by actual experience in the field of risk management to carry out the purposes of 37 
this chapter.  38 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 622 - 128LR 2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  3.  Personnel.   The director  State Controller  may employ such assistants and 1 
employees  as are necessary, and distribute the risk management duties among such 2 
persons as the director  State Controller  considers necessary for economy and efficiency 3 
of administration. Employees are subject to the Civil Service Law.  4 
Sec. O -2.  5 MRSA §1727 -A, as enacted by PL 1983, c. 349, §7, is amended to 5 
read:  6 
§1727 -A.  Conflict of interest prohibited  7 
The director  State Controller  or any other  employee of the division shall  may not be 8 
financially interested, directly or indirectly, in any insurer, agency or in surance 9 
transaction, except as a policyholder or claimant under a policy, nor shall  may the 10 
director  State Controller  or any other  employee be licensed under Title 24 -A, as an agent, 11 
broker, consultant or adjuster.  12 
Sec. O -3.  5 MRSA §1728 -A, as amended by PL 1993, c. 470, §1, is further 13 
amended to read:  14 
§1728 -A.  Powers and duties of the State Controller  15 
1.  Duties.   The director  State Controller  shall provide insurance advice and services 16 
for all forms of insurance for State Government and any department o r agency of State 17 
Government except for those departments or agencies and those types of insurance 18 
otherwise provided for by law through the self -insurance fund and to other entities 19 
designated as entitled to advice and services through the state -administe red fund pursuant 20 
to section 1737.  The director  State Controller  is responsible for the acquisition and 21 
administration of all insurance purchased by the State, including the authority to purchase 22 
insurance for the State for automobile, fire, liability and  any other type of coverage 23 
necessary to protect the State from financial loss. The director  State Controller  may enter 24 
into contracts for various types of claims management services in order to ensure the 25 
most economically advantageous insurance protectio n in the operation of the State's 26 
insurance coverage program.  In these regards, the director  State Controller  has the 27 
following duties:  28 
A.  To review annually the entire subject of insurance as it applies to all state 29 
property and activities and other per sons pursuant to this section, and to provide to 30 
the Commissioner of Administrative and Financial Services a statement of its 31 
activities during the year ending the preceding June 30th. This report must include:  32 
(1)  An evaluation of the state insurance pr ogram;  33 
(2)  A complete statement of all types and costs of insurance in effect;  34 
(3)  Names of agents and companies of record; and  35 
(4)  Such other matters as the director  State Controller  determines appropriate 36 
and necessary or as the commissioner may re quest;  37 
B.  To recommend to the Commissioner of Administrative and Financial Services 38 
such insurance protection as the director  State Controller  considers necessary or 39 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 623 - 128LR2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  desirable for the protection of all state property or activities or other insureds under 1 
this section;  2 
C.  Pursuant to programs approved by the Commissioner of Administrative and 3 
Financial Services, to provide insurance protection for property and liability in 4 
accordance with the Maine Tort Claims Act, Title 14, section 8116, and premises 5 
liability, when required by a state lease or private property approved by the Attorney 6 
General, by self -insured retention or purchase of insurance from companies or agents 7 
licensed to do business in this State, or by both, to effect the best possible contracts  as 8 
to services, coverages and costs. The purchase of insurance under this section 9 
normally must be made upon competitive bidding, except that the director  State 10 
Controller  may, in appropriate circumstances, purchase insurance by negotiation;  11 
D.  To determ ine and review the values of property in which the State has an 12 
insurable or legal interest and recommend limits and types of insurance protection for 13 
that property;  14 
E.  To establish and promote safety and other loss prevention programs;  15 
F.  To receive and , with the assistance of the Attorney General, administer all claims 16 
for personal injury and property damage against the State;  17 
G.  With the assistance of the Attorney General, to pursue all claims against 3rd 18 
parties in all cases in which the State may be  subrogated to the rights of injured 19 
employees or where damage to state property may have resulted from the negligence 20 
of a 3rd party;  21 
H.  To administer the funds established by sections 1731 and 1737.  In performing the 22 
functions authorized by this chapte r, the funds, the Commissioner of Administrative 23 
and Financial Services and the director  State Controller  are not subject to the 24 
provisions of Title 24 -A; and  25 
I.  On or before December 31, 1996 and every 3 years thereafter, to submit to the 26 
Commissioner of  Administrative and Financial Services a report on the availability 27 
and affordability of insurance advice and services to those entities participating in the 28 
state-administered fund pursuant to section 1737 and to make specific 29 
recommendations for the remo val from the state -administered fund of those entities 30 
that do not qualify.  31 
2.  Appraisal.   In case an agreement as to the amount of loss sustained to any 32 
building or property insured under this chapter can not be arrived at between the insured 33 
entity and the director  State Controller , the loss must be referred to appraisal as provided 34 
by Title 24 -A, section 3002.  35 
3.  Rejection of risk.   In the event that the director  State Controller  determines that a 36 
risk may be prejudicial to the State's insurance progr am or to the state -administered fund 37 
established by section 1737 because of an actual or expected adverse loss ratio, the 38 
director  State Controller  may refuse to include that risk in the program until the time that 39 
the hazards of the risk have been removed  or ameliorated to a satisfactory degree.  40 
When coverage is declined by the director  State Controller , the department, agency or 41 
entity in charge of the risk may request that the director  State Controller  procure separate 42 
insurance from any authorized insur ance company, and the premium for that separate 43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 624 - 128LR 2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  insurance is a proper charge against the department, agency or entity responsible for the 1 
property.  2 
4.  Forms and rules.   The director  State Controller  may prescribe forms of policies, 3 
proofs of loss and othe r forms and may adopt rules as are necessary or expedient for the 4 
proper administration of this chapter.  5 
5.  Actuarial review.   Once every 3 years, and more frequently if determined prudent 6 
by the Commissioner of Administrative and Financial Services, the director  State 7 
Controller  shall arrange for a review of the reserves of the state -administered fund by a 8 
qualified actuary who is a member in good standing of the Casualty Actuarial Society.  9 
The actuary shall issue an opinion on the adequacy of reserves o f the state -administered 10 
fund to cover the estimated ultimate liability of the state -administered fund.  Costs for 11 
this service must be paid from the Risk Management Fund.  12 
Sec. O -4.  5 MRSA §1731, first ¶, as amended by PL 1993, c. 470, §2, is further 13 
amen ded to read:  14 
A reserve fund, referred to in this chapter as the "self -insurance fund," is created to 15 
indemnify the State or the State's designated payee for self -insured retention losses and 16 
related loss adjustment expenses from those perils insured agains t under a deductible or 17 
self-insured retention program, as recommended by the director  State Controller  and 18 
approved by the Commissioner of Administrative and Financial Services.  With the 19 
approval of the commissioner, the self -insurance fund may be used f or loss prevention 20 
programs administered by either the risk management division within the Bureau of 21 
General Services  Office of the State Controller  or the Bureau of Human Resources.  The 22 
total amount of the self -insurance fund provided for loss prevention  programs in any 23 
given year may not exceed 5% of the self -insurance fund as of July 1st of that fiscal year.  24 
The self -insurance fund is a continuing fund and does not lapse.  Funds provided from the 25 
self-insurance fund to the Bureau of Human Resources are  similarly nonlapsing and are 26 
carried forward through the Bureau of Human Resources' Dedicated Revenue Account.  27 
Sec. O -5.  5 MRSA §1731 -A, last ¶, as amended by PL 1983, c. 349, §13, is 28 
further amended to read:  29 
The director  State Controller  may purchase su ch reinsurance of the deductible or self - 30 
insured retentions hereunder as he the State Controller  may deem  consider  necessary or 31 
desirable.  The director  State Controller  may purchase such reinsurance protection from 32 
companies or agents licensed or approved  by the Superintendent of Insurance to do 33 
business in the State.  34 
Sec. O -6.  5 MRSA §1733, last ¶, as amended by PL 1993, c. 470, §5, is further 35 
amended to read:  36

rata basi s as determined by the director  State Controller  and based on the prior claims 38 
experience of the departments or agencies.  39

Sec. O -9.  5 MRSA §1737, sub -§§1 to 3, as enacted by PL 1993, c. 470, §9, are 12 
amended to read:  13 
1.  Creation of stat e-administered fund.   A reserve fund, referred to in this chapter 14 
as the "state -administered fund," is created to indemnify persons and entities eligible for 15 
participation pursuant to subsection 2 for losses and related loss adjustment expenses 16 
from those perils insured against under a deductible or self -insured retention program as 17 
recommended by the director  State Controller  and approved by the Commissioner of 18 
Administrative and Financial Services.  With the approval of the commissioner, the state - 19 
adminis tered fund may be used for loss prevention programs administered by the risk 20 
management division within the Bureau of General Services  Office of the State 21 
Controller .  The total amount of the state -administered fund provided for loss prevention 22 
programs in  any given year may not exceed 5% of the state -administered fund as of July 23 
1st of that fiscal year.  The state -administered fund is a continuing fund and does not 24 
lapse.  25 
2.  Eligibility for participation in state -administered fund.   The director  State 26 
Controller  may offer insurance advice and services to persons or entities other than state 27 
departments or agencies if:  28 
A.  The director  State Controller  has been authorized to do so by law;  29 
B.  The Governor has approved that person or entity for insurance adv ice and service;  30 
C.  Coverage is unavailable or is offered only at unreasonable cost to that person or 31 
entity; and  32 
D.  That person or entity has demonstrated a strong public need for the services 33 
provided by that person or entity.  34 
3.  Interim coverage.   The director  State Controller  may offer insurance advice and 35 
services for no more than 6 months when the Governor, in the absence of the Legislature, 36 
determines that it is appropriate to do so based on consideration of the risks involved and 37 
the governmental  objectives served by that coverage.  38

amended to read:  40

Sec. O -11.  5 MRSA §1737, sub -§8, as enacted by PL 1993, c. 470, §9, is 13 
amended to read:  14 
8.  Payments from state -administered fund.   Pursuant to the reco mmendation of 15 
the director  State Controller , the Commissioner of Administrative and Financial Services 16 
may cause payments from the state -administered fund or proceeds of insurance purchased 17 
in accordance with this section, or both, to be made available for  repair or replacement of 18 
insured property and payment of losses and loss adjustment expenses.  The rights of a 19 
person or entity insured under this section are limited to the extent specified in the 20 
contractual agreements or policies of insurance entered i nto between those persons or 21 
entities and the director  State Controller  and any involved insurance companies.  22 
Notwithstanding any contractual agreements or policies of insurance, persons or entities 23 
participating in the state -administered fund do not have  a right of recovery except against 24 
the assets of the state -administered fund and do not have recourse against the General 25 
Fund, the assets of the State or the commissioner, the director  State Controller  or any 26 
other state employee.  The commissioner shall  establish procedures to ensure adequate 27 
disclosure of this limitation on rights of recovery to the entities insured under this section.  28

PART X  24 
Sec. X -1.  Attrition savings.  Notwithstanding any provision of law to the 25 
contrary, the attrition rate for the 2018 -2019 biennium is increased from 1.6% to 5% for 26 
judicial branch and executive branch departments and agencies only, with the exception 27 
of the District Attorneys Salaries program within the Department of the Attorney 28 
General. The attrition rate for subsequent biennia is 1.6% with the exception of the 29 
District Attorneys Salaries program within the Department of the Attorney General. The 30 
attriti on rate for the District Attorneys Salaries program is 0% for the 2018 -2019 31 
biennium.  32 
Sec. X -2.  Calculation and transfer; attrition savings.  The State Budget 33 
Officer shall calculate the amount of the savings in section 3 of this Part that applies 34 
against  each General Fund account for all executive branch departments and agencies 35

transfer the amounts by financial order upon the approval of the Governor. These 2 
transfers are considered adjustments to appropriations in fiscal years 2017 -18 and 2018 - 3 
19. The State Budget Officer shall submit to the Joint Standing Committee on 4 
Appropriations and Financial Affairs a report of the transferred amounts no later than 5 
September 1, 2018.  6

PART CC  5 
Sec. CC -1.  Voluntary employee incentive programs.  Notwithstanding the 6 
Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 903, subsect ions 1 and 2, the Commissioner of 7 
Administrative and Financial Services shall offer for use prior to July 1, 2019 special 8 
voluntary employee incentive programs for state employees, including a 50% workweek, 9 
flexible position staffing and time off without p ay. Employee participation in a voluntary 10 
employee incentive program is subject to the approval of the employee's appointing 11 
authority.  12 
Sec. CC -2.  Continuation of group health insurance.  Notwithstanding the 13 
Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 285, s ubsection 7 and Title 5, section 903, the 14 
State shall continue to pay health and dental insurance benefits for a state employee who 15 
applies prior to July 1, 2019 and is approved to participate in a voluntary employee 16 
incentive program under section 1 of th is Part based upon the scheduled workweek in 17 
effect prior to the employee's participation in the voluntary employee incentive program.  18 
Sec. CC -3.  Continuation of group life insurance.  Notwithstanding the Maine 19 
Revised Statutes, Title 5, sections 903 and 18056 and the rules of the Maine Public 20 
Employees Retirement System, the life, accidental death and dismemberment, 21 
supplemental and dependent insurance amounts for a state employee who applies prior to 22 
July 1, 2019 and is approved to participate in a volun tary employee incentive program 23 
under section 1 of this Part are based upon the scheduled hours of the employee prior to 24 
the employee's participation in the voluntary employee incentive program.  25 
Sec. CC -4.  General Fund savings.  Notwithstanding the Maine Revised 26 
Statutes, Title 5, section 1585, the State Budget Officer shall transfer the General Fund 27 
savings resulting from the voluntary employee incentive programs under section 1 of this 28 
Part to the General Fund Compensation and Benefit Plan account in the  Department of 29 
Administrative and Financial Services. The State Budget Officer shall submit to the joint 30 
standing committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over appropriations and 31 
financial affairs a report of the transferred amounts no later than J anuary 15, 2019 for 32 
fiscal year 2017 -18 and no later than January 15, 2020 for fiscal year 2018 -19. 33 
Sec. CC -5.  Lapsed balances.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law, 34 
$350,000 in fiscal year 2017 -18 and $350,000 in fiscal year 2018 -19 of savings ide ntified 35 
from the voluntary employee incentive programs in this Part lapse to the General Fund.  36

PART RR  13 
Sec. RR -1.  10 MRSA c. 501, sub -c. 4-A is enac ted to read:  14 
SUBCHAPTER 4 -A 15 
LOCAL SEALERS  16 
§2461.  Election by municipal officers  17 
The municipal officers of a municipality may elect or appoint a sealer of weights and 18 
measures, and a deputy sealer if necessary, not necessarily a resident of that municipali ty, 19 
and the sealer and deputy sealer hold office during their efficiency and the faithful 20 
performance of their duties.  On complaint being made to the municipal officers of the 21 
inefficiency or neglect of duty of a sealer or deputy sealer, the municipal off icers shall set 22 
a date for and give notice of a hearing to the complainant, the relevant sealer and the state 23 
sealer. If evidence satisfies the municipal officers that the sealer or deputy sealer has been 24 
inefficient or has neglected the sealer's or deputy  sealer's duty, they may remove the 25 
sealer or deputy sealer from office and elect or appoint another in the sealer's or deputy 26 
sealer's stead. The state sealer has jurisdiction over a sealer or deputy sealer elected or 27 
appointed pursuant to this section, a nd any vacancy caused by death or resignation must 28 
be filled by election or appointment by the municipal officers within 30 days. For each 29 
month that the municipal officers neglect their duty, they severally are subject to a fine of 30 
$10. Within 10 days aft er each such election or appointment, the clerk of each 31 
municipality shall communicate the name of the person so elected or appointed to the 32 
state sealer and for neglect of this duty is subject to a fine of $10. A sealer of weights and 33 
measures in any muni cipality may be sealer for several municipalities, if such is the 34 
pleasure of the municipal officers of those municipalities, as long as this action receives 35 
the approval of the state sealer.  36 
§2462.  Appointment by state sealer  37 
The municipal officers of a municipality may request the state sealer to appoint a 38 
qualified person to serve as sealer of weights and measures in lieu of local appointment or 39 
election as provided for in section 2461. If the municipal officers fail to elect or appoint a 40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 637 - 128LR2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  sealer and mak e a return to the state sealer of the election or appointment within 30 days 1 
after the election or appointment, the state sealer may appoint a qualified person to act as 2 
sealer of weights and measures. Any person appointed under this section may serve in 3 
that capacity for more than one municipality.  4 
§2463.  Powers and duties  5 
A weights and measures official elected or appointed for a municipality has the duties 6 
enumerated in section 2402, subsections 2 to 9 and the powers enumerated in section 7 
2403. These po wers and duties extend to the official's jurisdiction.  8 
§2464.  Records of weights and measures sealed; annual report  9 
A sealer shall keep records of all weights and measures, balances and measuring 10 
devices inspected, sealed or condemned by that sealer, givi ng the name of the owner or 11 
agent, the place of business, the date of inspection and kind of apparatus inspected, sealed 12 
or condemned. The sealer shall make an annual report on July 1st for the 12 preceding 13 
months on forms prescribed by the state sealer an d shall furnish such information as the 14 
state sealer may require.  15

average age, both in aggregate and by primary disability type, at which 40

learning through technology program.  Pursuant to the Maine Revised Statutes, 5

support systems for students and educators to support the operations of the Department of 8

exceed 4 years in duration and $50,000,000 in principal costs for the Department of 10 
Education's learning through technology program. The interest rate may not exceed 8%, 11 
and the total interest costs may not exceed $4,000,000. The annua l principal and interest 12 
costs must be paid from the appropriate line category allocations in the Department of 13 
Education. The State is authorized to extend the provisions of the lease -purchase 14 
agreement on behalf of school administrative units as long as all costs of the extension 15 
are borne by the school administrative units.  16

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §17-A.  Publications and technology  1 
1.  Informational publications and record searches.   The State Court 2 
Administrator may establish a fee schedule to cover the cost of printing and distribution 3 
of publications and forms, the procedures for the sale of these publications and forms and 4 
record se arches performed by Judicial Department employees . 5 
2.  Fund; fees deposited.   All fees collected under this section from the sale of 6 
publications or forms must be deposited in a fund for use by the State Court 7 
Administrator to fund publications, forms and information technology.  Twenty percent 8 
of fees collected for record searches under subsection 1  must be deposited in the fund, 9 
and 80% of fees collected for such record searches must be deposited in the General 10 
Fund.  11 
3.  Fees and surcharges for electronic  filing.   The Supreme Judicial Court may by 12 
court rules or administrative orders raise or establish fees for online case searches 13 
performed by Judicial Department employees and electronic document delivery and case 14 
filings and surcharges on fines to suppor t the operating costs of maintaining an electronic 15 
filing and court information management system.  All revenues collected under this 16 
subsection must be deposited in a fund to be used for those operating costs, including, but 17 
not limited to, costs of elect ronic filing, imaging and hardware, software maintenance 18 
fees and hardware maintenance fees and personnel costs.  19

the determination of the Director of Unemployment Compensation or its 15

to Title 5, section 11001 et seq. In the absence of appeal therefrom, the determination 23 
of the commission, together with the record of the proceeding under this subsection, 24 
shall be  is admissible in any s ubsequent material proceeding under this chapter, and if 25 
supported by evidence, and in the absence of fraud, shall be  is conclusive, except as 26 
to errors of law, upon any employing unit which  that was a party to the proceeding 27 
under this subsection.  28

§1226.  Appeal of determination or assessment  31

notification is mailed to the employer's last known address as it appears in the records 38 
of the bureau or, in the absence of such mailing, within 30 days after the notification 39 
is delivered.  If the employer fails to perfect this appeal, the assessment or 40 
determination is final as to law and fact.  41 
B.  Upon appeal from such assessment or determination the commission  Division of 42 
Administrative Hearings  shall, after affording the appellant and the co mmissioner's 43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 658 - 128LR 2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  designated representative a reasonable opportunity for a fair hearing, make finding of 1 
facts and render its decision, which may affirm, modify or reverse the action of the 2 
designated representative. The conduct of the hearings shall be  is gove rned by 3 
regulations  rules  of the commission consistent with Title 5, section 9051 et seq. The 4 
commission  Division of Administrative Hearings  shall promptly notify the parties to 5 
the proceeding of its finding of facts and its decision. The decision shall be  is subject 6 
to appeal to the commission, which may affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the 7 
Division of Administrative Hearings based on the evidence presented or may remand 8 
the case to the Division of Administrative Hearings for further hearing pursu ant to the 9 
commission's rules.  The decision of the commission is subject to  appeal pursuant to 10 
Title 5, section 11001 et seq. The commissioner shall have  has the right to appeal a 11 
final decision of the Maine Unemployment Insurance Commission  commission  to the 12 
Superior Court.  13

refunds or credit, insofar as such determination or decision necessarily involves the issue 17

PART CCCCC  23 
Sec. CCCCC -1.  26 MRSA §1191, sub -§3, as amended by PL 2009, c. 466, §1, 24 
is further amended to read:  25 
3.  Weekly b enefit for partial unemployment.   Each eligible individual who is 26 
partially unemployed in any week must be paid a partial benefit for that week.  The 27 
partial benefit is equal to the weekly benefit amount less the individual's weekly earnings 28 
in excess of an amount that is referred to in this subsection as a residual amount.  Until 29 
December 31, 2017, the residual amount is  $25, and beginning the first full benefit week 30 
beginning on or after January 1, 2018, the residual amount is $100.  Starting on January 31 
1, 2019 and on each January 1st thereafter, the residual amount must be increased by the 32 
increase, if any, in the cost of living.  The increase in the cost of living must be measured 33 
by the percentage increase, if any, as of August of the previous year over  the level as of 34 
August of the year preceding that year in the Consumer Price Index for Urban Wage 35 
Earners and Clerical Workers, CPI -W, for the Northeast Region, or its successor index, as 36 
published by the United States Department of Labor, Bureau of Labor  Statistics or its 37 
successor agency .  The following amounts are not considered wages for purposes of this 38 
subsection:  39 
A.  Amounts received from the Federal Government by a member of the National 40 
Guard and organized reserve, including base pay and allowance s; 41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 659 - 128LR2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  B.  Amounts received as a volunteer firefighter or as a volunteer emergency medical 1 
services person;  2 
C.  Amounts received as an elected member of the Legislature; and  3 
D.  Earnings for the week received as a result of participation in full -time training 4 
under the United States Trade Act of 1974 as amended by the United States Trade 5 
and Globalization Adjustment Assistance Act of 2009 up to an amount equal to the 6 
individual’s most recent weekly benefit amount.  7

§1, is further amended to read:  9 
A.  At the time the status of an employing unit is ascertained to be that of an 10 
employer, the commissioner shall establish and maintain, until the employer status is 11 
terminated, for the employer an experience rating record, to which are credited all the 12 
contributions that the employer pays on the employer's own behalf. This chapter may 13 
not be construed to grant any employer or individuals in the employer's service prior 14 
claims or rights to the amount s paid by the employer into the fund. Benefits paid to 15 
an eligible individual under the Maine  Employment Security Law must be charged 16 
against the experience rating record of the claimant's most recent subject employer , 17 
except that, beginning January 1, 201 8, benefits paid to an eligible individual under 18 
the Employment Security Law must be charged against the experience rating record 19 
of the claimant's employers in a ratio inversely proportional to the claimant's 20 
employment beginning with the most recent empl oyer,  or to the General Fund if the 21 
otherwise chargeable experience rating record is that of an employer whose status as 22 
such has been terminated; except that no charge may be made to an individual 23 
employer but must be made to the General Fund if the commi ssion finds that:  24 
(1)  The claimant's separation from the claimant's last employer was for 25 
misconduct in connection with the claimant's employment or was voluntary 26 
without good cause attributable to the employer;  27 
(2)  The claimant has refused to accept r eemployment in suitable work when 28 
offered by a previous employer, without good cause attributable to the employer;  29

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (1)  The commissioner shall prepare a schedule listi ng all employers for whom a 1 
reserve ratio has been computed pursuant to this paragraph, in the order of their 2 
reserve ratios, beginning with the highest ratio.  For each employer, the schedule 3 
must show:  4 
(a)  The amount of the employer's reserve ratio;  5 
(b)  The amount of the employer's annual taxable payroll; and  6 
(c)  A cumulative total consisting of the amount of the employer's annual 7 
taxable payroll plus the amount of the annual taxable payrolls of all other 8 
employers preceding the employer on the list.  9 
(2)  The commissioner shall segregate employers into contribution categories in 10 
accordance with the cumulative totals under subparagraph (1), division (c).  The 11 
contribution category is determined by the cumulative payroll percentage limits 12 
in column B.  Ea ch contribution category is identified by the contribution 13 
category number in column A that is opposite the figures in column B, which 14 
represent the percentage limits of each contribution category.  If an employer's 15 
taxable payroll falls in more than one c ontribution category, the employer must 16 
be assigned to the lower -numbered contribution category, except that an 17 
employer may not be assigned to a higher contribution category than is assigned 18 
any other employer with the same reserve ratio.  19

(4)  The commissioner shall compute the predetermined yield by multiplying the 22 
ratio of total wages to taxable wages for the preceding calendar year by the 23 
planned yield.  24 
(5)  The commissioner shall determine the contribution rates effective for a rate 25 
year by multiplying the predetermined yield by the experience factors for each 26 
contribution category.  Contribution category 20 in the table in subparagraph (2) 27 
must be assigned a contribution rate of at least 5.4%.  The employer's experience 28 
factor is the percentage shown in column C in the table in subparagraph (2) that 29 
corresponds with the employer's contribution category in col umn A, except that 30 
the experience factors in column E must be used to determine the contribution 31 
rates for rate years 2000 and 2001 and those in column D must be used for rate 32 
years 2002 and 2003.  Beginning January 1, 2018, for rate years when schedule A 33 
is in effect as determined in subparagraph (3 -A), the experience factor in 34 
subparagraph (2) for contribution category 1 is assigned an experience factor of 35 
0.00 in column C.  36 
(6)  If, subsequent to the assignment of contribution rates for a rate year, the 37 
reserve ratio of an employer is recomputed and changed, the employer must be 38 
placed in the position on the schedule prepared pursuant to subparagraph (1) that 39 
the employer would have occupied had the corrected reserve ratio been shown on 40 
the schedule.  The altered position on the schedule does not affect the position of 41 
any other employer.  42 19 90.01  95.00  2.20 2.05000  1.9000

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (7)  In computing the contribution rates, only the wages reported by employers 1 
liable for payment of contributions into the fund and net benefits paid that are 2 
charged to an employer's experience rating record or to the fund are considered in 3 
the computation of the average benefit cost rate and the ratio of total wages to 4 
taxable wages.  5 
(8)  Beginning January 1, 2008, all contribution rates must be reduced by the 6 
Competitiv e Skills Scholarship Fund predetermined yield as defined in section 7 
1166, subsection 1, paragraph C, except that contribution category 20 under this 8 
paragraph may not be reduced below 5.4%.  9

PART EEEEE  12 
Sec. EEE EE-1.  12 MRSA §6301 -A is enacted to read:  13 
§6301 -A.  Coastal Fisheries Research, Management and Enforcement surcharges  14 
Beginning in licensing year 2018, the following surcharges are assessed and accrue to 15 
the Coastal Fisheries Research, Management and Enfo rcement Fund established in 16 
subsection 8.  17 
1.  Surcharges on resident lobster and crab fishing licenses.  For resident lobster 18 
and crab fishing licenses issued pursuant to section 6421, subsection 1, the following 19 
surcharges apply:  20 
A.  For a resident Class I license for applicants under 18 years of age, $18;  21 
B.  For a resident Class I license for applicants 18 years of age or older, $38;  22 
C.  For a resident Class I license for applicants 70 years of age or older, $19;  23 
D.  For a resident Class II license for a pplicants under 70 years of age, $76;  24 
E.  For a resident Class II license for applicants 70 years of age or older, $38;  25 
F.  For a resident Class III license for applicants under 70 years of age, $114;  26 
G.  For a resident Class III license for applicants 70 years of age or older, $55;  27 
H.  For a resident apprentice lobster and crab fishing license for applicants under 18 28 
years of age, $18;  29 
I.  For a resident apprentice lobster and crab fishing license for applicants 18 years of 30 
age or older but under 70 years of age, $37;  31 
J.  For a resident apprentice lobster and crab fishing license for applicants 70 years of 32 
age or older, $19;  33 
K.  For a student lobster and crab fishing license, $18; and  34 
L.  For a noncommercial lobster and crab fishing license, $18.  35 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390

8.  Coastal Fisheries Research, Management and Enforcement Fund.  The 6 
Coastal Fisheries Research, Management and Enforcement  Fund, referred to in this 7 
subsection as "the fund," is established within the department. The fund receives all funds 8 
deposited by the commissioner pursuant to this section. All money received by the fund 9 
must be used to fund scientific research, manageme nt or enforcement activities related to 10 
marine resources.  Unexpended balances in the fund at the end of a fiscal year do not 11 
lapse but must be carried forward to the next fiscal year to be used for the purposes of the 12 
fund. Any interest earned on the mone y in the fund must be credited to the fund.  13

Sec. IIIII -1.  8 MRSA §1003 , sub -§5 is enacted to read:  24 
5.  Additional duties of the director.  The director also serves as the director of the 25 
Gambling Control Unit, established as a bureau within the Department of Public Safety 26 
under Title 25, section 2902, subsection 12.  As dire ctor of the unit, the director shall 27 
administer and enforce the laws governing beano and games of chance under Title 17, 28 
chapters 13 -A and 62, respectively.  29 
PART JJJJJ  30 
Sec. JJJJJ -1.  17 MRSA §311, as amended by PL 2001, c. 342, §1, is further 31 
amended to re ad: 32 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 670 - 128LR 2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §311.  Definitions  1 
As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following words 2 
shall  have the following meanings.  3 
1.  Beano.   "Beano" means a specific kind of group game of chance, regardless of 4 
whether such a game is character ized by another name. Wherever the term "beano" is 5 
used, the word "bingo" or any other word used to characterize such a game may be 6 
interchanged. In "beano," each participant is given or sold one or more tally cards, so - 7 
called, each of which contains prepr inted numbers or letters and may or may not be 8 
arranged in vertical or horizontal rows. The participant covers or marks the numbers or 9 
letters as objects similarly numbered or lettered are drawn from a receptacle and the 10 
winner or winners are determined by  the sequence in which those objects are drawn.  The 11 
manner in which the winner is determined must be clearly announced or displayed before 12 
any game is begun.  Until July 1, 1994, a game described in this subsection is "beano" 13 
and a licensee may conduct su ch a game regardless of whether the manner of determining 14 
the winner is specifically described as a permissible manner of determining the winner in 15 
rules adopted by the Chief of State Police.   For the purposes of this chapter, to hold, 16 
conduct or operate b eano includes charging a fee or offering something of value to play 17 
in exchange for the opportunity to receive something of value for winning a game.  18 
1-A.  Commercial beano hall permit.   "Commercial beano hall permit" means 19 
written authority from the Chief  of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  issued to a 20 
permittee who rents or leases premises for profit to a licensee to hold, conduct or operate 21 
"beano."  22 
1-B.  Chief of State Police.   "Chief of the State Police" or "chief" means the Chief of 23 
the State Po lice or the chief's designee.  24 
2.  Equipment.  "Equipment" shall mean  means  the receptacle and numbered objects 25 
to be drawn from it; the master board upon which such objects are placed as drawn; the 26 
tally cards or sheets bearing such numbers to be covered an d the objects used to cover 27 
them; the boards or signs, however operated, used to display the numbers as they are 28 
drawn; public address systems; and any other articles essential to the operation, conduct 29 
and playing of "Beano."  30 
2-A.  Director.  "Director" m eans the Executive Director of the Gambling Control 31 
Board and the Gambling Control Unit.  32 
2-B.  Gambling Control Unit.  "Gambling Control Unit" or "unit" means the bureau 33 
within the Department of Public Safety under Title 25, section 2902, subsection 12 or an 34 
authorized representative of the Gambling Control Unit.  35 
3.  License.  "License" shall mean that  means  written authority from the Chief of the 36 
State Police  Gambling Control Unit  to hold, conduct or operate the amusement 37 
commonly known as  "Beano" for the e ntertainment of the public within the State of 38 
Maine. A location permit must accompany the license to be valid . 39 
4.  Licensee.  "Licensee" shall mean  means  any organization which , including a 40 
federally recognized Indian tribe in the State, that  has been gran ted a license by the Chief 41 
of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  to hold, conduct or operate "Beano" or 42 
"Bingo."  43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 671 - 128LR2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  5.  Location permit.  "Location permit" shall mean  means  that card issued by the 1 
Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit , describing  the premises or area in which 2 
"Beano" may be conducted. Such location permit must be accompanied by a license. 3 
Only such locations expressly described in the location permit shall be  are used for the 4 
conduct of any game.  5 
6.  Organization.  "Organization" shall mean  means  any firm, association or 6 
corporation authorized to conduct "Beano" in accordance with this chapter.  7 
7.  Period.  "Period" shall mean  means  the number of calendar weeks authorized by a 8 
single license for the operation of "Beano" or "Bingo."  9 
7-A.  Permittee.   "Permittee" means an individual, corporation, partnership or 10 
unincorporated association that rents or leases a building or facilities for profit to a 11 
licensee to hold, conduct or operate "beano."  12 
7-B.  Wild number beano.   "Wild number bean o" means a beano occasion, game or 13 
series of beano games in which a number is picked or denoted as a wild number that may 14 
be used to fill any number or letter on a beano card.  15 
8.  Winner -take-all round.   "Winner -take-all round" means a beano game or series  16 
of beano games in which all the proceeds from the sale of the cards for that round are 17 
paid to participants as prizes during that round.  18 
9.  Registrant.  "Registrant" means a person or organization registered with the 19 
Gambling Control Unit to hold, conduc t or operate beano games for which a license is not 20 
required.  21 
Sec. JJJJJ -2.  17 MRSA §312, sub -§1, as enacted by PL 2003, c. 452, Pt. I, §2 22 
and affected by Pt. X, §2, is amended to read:  23 
1.  License or registration required; restricted hours.   A person, fi rm, association 24 
or corporation may not hold, conduct or operate the amusement commonly known as  25 
"beano" or "bingo" for the entertainment of the public  within the State unless that person, 26 
firm, association or corporation has obtained a license from  submitt ed a registration that 27 
was subsequently accepted by  the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit.  A 28 
person may not conduct high -stakes beano under section 314 -A without a license issued 29 
by the Gambling Control Unit.  A registration or license to co nduct beano under this 30 
chapter may not be assigned or transferred . 31
