Sec. JJJJJ -7.  17 MRSA §§313 -C, 313 -D and 313 -E are enacted to read:  8 
§313 -C.  Organizations eligible for registration; fees  9 
1.  Registration eligibility.  The Gambling Control Unit may accept registrations 10 
from the following organizatio ns to conduct beano to be conducted by duly authorized 11 
members for the exclusive benefit of the organization:  12 
A.  A volunteer fire department;  13 
B.  An agricultural fair association;  14 
C.  A bona fide nonprofit, charitable, educational, political, civic, recre ational, 15 
fraternal, patriotic, religious or veterans organization that has been in existence and 16 
founded, chartered or organized in the State for at least 2 years prior to its 17 
registration; and  18 
D.  An auxiliary organization associated with an organization,  department or 19 
association described in this subsection that has been in existence for at least 2 years 20 
prior to submitting a registration to conduct beano to the Gambling Control Unit.  21 
The Gambling Control Unit may accept a registration submitted by an or ganization 22 
described in paragraph C that has been in existence for less than 2 years in the State if the 23 
organization has a charter from a national organization.  24 
2.  Fees.  Registration fees to conduct beano are as follows.  25 
A.  For up to a calendar week, t he fee is $12.  26 
B.  For up to a calendar month, the fee is $36.  27 
C.  For up to a calendar year, the fee is $400.  28 
D.  The fee for a single game is $5. An organization is limited to 6 single -game 29 
registrations in a calendar year.  30 
Registration fees required by this subsection must accompany a registration submitted to 31 
the Gambling Control Unit and must be credited to the General Fund.  32 
§313 -D.  Registration exceptions  33 
Notwithstanding section 312, subsection 1 and section 313 -E, and subject to the 34 
conditions set o ut in this section, the following organizations may conduct beano without 35 
a license or without registering with the Gambling Control Unit.  36 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 673 - 128LR2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  1.  Senior organizations.  Clubs, groups or organizations composed of individuals at 1 
least 90% of whom are 62 years o f age or older when beano is conducted for their own 2 
entertainment and not for profit.  3 
2.  Campgrounds.  A campground licensed under Title 22, section 2492 or a 4 
campground operated by the State Government or the Federal Government when:  5 
A.  Beano is offere d exclusively to campground patrons and guests of campground 6 
patrons;  7 
B.  A prize awarded to a winner of a beano game does not exceed a value of $25 for 8 
any one game; and  9 
C.  Proceeds from fees charged to campground patrons and their guests to participate 10 
in a beano game are used only to pay for prizes awarded to players and to cover the 11 
actual costs incurred to operate the games.  12 
3.  Resort hotels. A bona fide resort hotel, which includes a full -service hotel facility 13 
and offers leisure and recreational ac tivities to its patrons, such as tennis, golf or 14 
horseback riding, when:  15 
A.  Beano is offered exclusively to resort hotel patrons and their guests;  16 
B.  A prize awarded to a winner of a beano game does not exceed a value of $25 for 17 
any one game; and  18 
C.  Proceeds from fees charged to resort hotel patrons and their guests to participate 19 
in a beano game are used only to pay for prizes awarded to players and to cover the 20 
actual costs incurred to operate the games.  21 
4.  Schools.  A school for children in kindergar ten to grade 8 when:  22 
A.  Games are offered exclusively to students and faculty of the school and their 23 
families;  24 
B.  A prize awarded to a winner of a beano game does not exceed a value of $25 for 25 
any one game; and  26 
C.  Proceeds from fees charged to particip ate in a beano game are used only to pay 27 
for prizes awarded to players, to support a parent -teacher organization associated 28 
with the school and to cover the actual costs incurred to operate the games.  29 
Notwithstanding section 319, persons under the age of 1 6 may take part in a game of 30 
beano conducted under subsection 2, 3 or 4.  31 
§313 -E.  Prize limits  32 
A single prize awarded for a game of beano may not exceed $400 in value and the 33 
total amount of prizes awarded on any one occasion may not exceed $1,400 in value  34 
except that once per calendar year on one occasion a registrant may award up to $2,000 in 35 
total prizes.  This section does not apply to high -stakes beano conducted in accordance 36 
with section 314 -A. 37

Sec. JJJJJ -10.  17 MRSA §314 -A, sub -§1-A, as amended by PL 2009, c. 505, 18 
§1, is further amended to read:  19 
1-A.  Sealed tickets.   The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may also 20 
issue to any  accept a registration from a  federally recognized Indian tribe licenses  21 
licensed under this section  to sell lucky seven or other similar sealed tickets in accordance 22 
with section 324 -A.  The licensee may operate a dispenser to sell the lucky seven or other 23 
similar tickets.  As used in this subsection, "dispenser" means a mechanical or electrical 24 
device or machine that, upon the insertion of money, credit or something of value, 25 
dispenses printed lucky seven or other similar tickets.  The element of chance must be 26 
provided by the ticket itself, not by the dispenser.  The Chief of the State Police  27 
Gambling Control Unit  may adopt rules to facilitate the use of dispensers.  Rules adopted 28 
pursuant to this subsection are routine technical rules as defined in Title 5, chapter 375, 29 
subchapter 2 -A. 30

Sec. JJJJJ -17.  17 MRSA §315 -A, as enacted by PL 2013, c. 305, §2, is amended 19 
to read:  20 
§315 -A.  Limited dual beano registration  21 
The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may issue a limited dual beano 22 
license  registration  to 2 organizations eligible for a regular license  registration  to conduct 23 
a game of beano.  A limited dual beano license  registration  permits 2 organizations to 24 
conduct beano jointl y on the same date and at the same location.  An organization may 25 
only conduct beano under the authority of a dual license  registration  on 2 occasions 26 
during a calendar year.  The following provisions apply to licensure  registration  under 27 
this section.  28 
1.  Application.  The 2 organizations wishing to conduct beano jointly shall submit 29 
an application to the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  in a manner 30 
prescribed by the chief  unit. 31 
2.  Lead registrant.  One organization must be identified as th e lead applicant  32 
registrant  and acknowledge responsibility for any violation of the laws or rules governing 33 
beano committed during the conduct of the game.  34 
3.  Disposition of revenue.  Revenue received from the conduct of the game must be 35 
divided in equal amounts between both organizations.  Each organization shall file a 36 
disposition of funds report as if that organization had conducted beano independently.  37 
4.  Registration fee.  The license  registration  fee for a limited dual beano license is 38 
$12. 39 
5.  Sealed tickets.  A limited dual beano license  registration  does not authorize the 40

petition the Superior Court in the county where the refusal occurred to find the 20 
witness in contempt.  The Attorney General shall c ause to be served on that witness 21 
an order requiring the witness to appear before the Superior Court to show cause why 22 
the witness should not be adjudged in contempt.  The court shall, in a summary 23 
manner, hear the evidence and, if it is such as to warrant  the court in doing so, punish 24 
that witness in the same manner and to the same extent as for contempt committed 25 
before the Superior Court or with reference to the process of the Superior Court.  26

Gambling Control Unit  shall notify the applicant, licensee , registrant  or permittee in 28 
writing, before a license , registration  or permit is denied, suspended or revoked pursuant 29 
to subsection 1, paragraph B or D, of the intended denia l or commencement date of the 30 
suspension or revocation, which may not be made any sooner than 96 hours after the 31 
licensee's , registrant's  or permittee's receipt of the notice, of the duration of the 32 
suspension or revocation and of the right to a hearing pu rsuant to this subsection.  The 33 
applicant, licensee , registrant  or permittee has the right to request a hearing before the 34 
Commissioner of Public Safety or the commissioner's designee.  Upon the applicant's, 35 
licensee's , registrant's  or permittee's request for a hearing, the Commissioner of Public 36 
Safety shall provide a hearing.  The hearing must comply with the Maine Administrative 37 
Procedure Act.  The purpose of the hearing is to determine whether a preponderance of 38 
the evidence establishes that the applica nt, applicant's agent or employee, licensee or 39 
licensee's agent or employee or registrant or registrant's agent or employee  violated a 40 
provision of this chapter or Title 17 -A, chapter 39 or the permittee or the permittee's 41 
employee committed murder or a Cl ass A, B or C crime or violated a provision of this 42 
chapter or Title 17 -A, chapter 15, 29, 37 or 39.  A request for a hearing may not be made 43 
any later than 10 days after the applicant, licensee , registrant  or permittee is notified of 44 
the proposed denial, suspension or revocation.  The suspension or revocation action must 45

Sec. JJJJJ -21.  17 MRSA §319, as enacted by PL 1975, c. 307, §2, is repealed 19 
and the following enacted in its place:  20 
§319.  Persons under 16 years of age  21 
Persons under 16 years of age are not permitted to take part  in the conduct of, nor 22 
participate in, the game of "beano" or "bingo," nor may persons under 16 years of age be 23 
admitted to the playing area unless accompanied by a parent, guardian or other 24 
responsible person.  25 
"Beano" or "bingo" games licensed or registe red under this chapter may not be 26 
conducted unless some person at least 18 years of age, who has been a member in good 27 
standing of the licensee or registrant for at least 2 years, exercises exclusive control of 28 
each game played.  29 
A license or registration f or the conduct of "beano" or "bingo" may not be issued to 30 
any firm, association, corporation or group composed wholly or primarily of persons 31 
under 16 years of age.  32 
Sec. JJJJJ -22.  17 MRSA §320, sub -§§1 and 2, as enacted by PL 2003, c. 452, 33 
Pt. I, §8 and a ffected by Pt. X, §2, are amended to read:  34 
1.  Liquor prohibited.   A licensee or registrant  may not conduct "beano" or "bingo" 35 
in the same room where liquor is sold, served or consumed during the period of one hour 36 
before the conduct of the games.  37 
2.  Diso rderly persons prohibited.   A licensee or registrant  may not permit a 38 
disorderly person to enter or remain within the room or area where "beano" or "bingo" 39 
games are being conducted.  40

amended to read:  11 
§326 .  Proceeds  12 
1-A.  Payment of proceeds.   An organization licensed or registered  to operate beano 13 
or bingo and Lucky 7 games in conjunction with beano or bingo may use the proceeds or 14 
part of the proceeds to:  15 
A.  Pay salaries, wages or remuneration to any pe rson directly involved in operating 16 
beano, bingo or Lucky 7 games;  17 
B.  Defray the expenses or part of the expenses that further the purpose for which the 18 
organization is formed except that proceeds may not be:  19 
(1)  Used to purchase alcohol or to defray the  cost of activities where alcohol is 20 
served; or  21 
(2)  Paid directly to organization members except as specifically allowed in this 22 
subsection; and  23 
C.  Defray the expenses or part of the expenses of a member, auxiliary member, 24 
officer or employee of the orga nization for a serious illness, injury or casualty loss if 25 
the licensee makes an application and the application is approved by the licensing 26 
division within the Bureau of State Police  Gambling Control Unit . 27 
(1)  An application must be made in the form and  contain the information the 28 
licensing division  unit requires.  29 
(a)  In the case of serious illness or injury, the licensing division  unit may 30 
require certification by a licensed physician setting out the facts in support of 31 
the application.  32 
(b)  In the cas e of a casualty loss, the licensing division  unit may require 33 
statements or reports from a law enforcement agency, rescue or other 34 
emergency services personnel or an insurance agency to support the 35 
application.  36 
(c)  The licensing division may deny an appli cation if it appears that the 37 
person who would receive the proceeds has adequate means of financial 38 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 681 - 128LR2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  support, including, but not limited to, insurance or workers' compensation 1 
benefits.  2 
1-B.  Filing.  An organization that chooses to use the proceeds or part of the proceeds 3 
as allowed by subsection 1 -A must file with the Chief of the State Police  Gambling 4 
Control Unit , at least quarterly, a form for the disposition of funds prescribed by the 5 
Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  detailing all payment s made.  Every 6 
statement on the form must be made under oath by an officer of the organization.  7 
2.  Rules.  The rules adopted pursuant to section 317 must contain standards 8 
governing payments made under this section.  Payments under subsection 1 -A, paragrap h 9 
A may not exceed 20% of the revenue generated by the games and the rules must limit 10 
payments to reasonable compensation, taking into account the nature of the services 11 
rendered, comparable wage rates, the size of the organization and other revenues, the size 12 
of the games and the revenue generated by the games.  The Chief of the State Police  13 
Gambling Control Unit  may disallow any excessive payment of proceeds, may suspend 14 
an organization's license or registration  for excessive payment of proceeds and may 15 
condition the restoration of an organization's license or registration  on the repayment of 16 
an excessive payment of proceeds by the organization.  17 
4.  Posting.   An organization licensed or registered  to operate beano or bingo and 18 
Lucky 7 games in conjunction with beano or bingo shall post in a conspicuous place in 19 
the room or hall where the licensed game is conducted a sign that states: the net revenue 20 
earned from the operation of those games in dollars and cents; the amount of charitable 21 
donations from that n et revenue in dollars and cents; what percentage in dollars and cents 22 
of the net revenue that amount represents in donations to nonprofit activities; and what 23 
percentage of the net revenue was distributed from licensed games for the previous 24 
calendar year and the current calendar year.  25

Sec. KKKKK -8.  17 MRSA §1831, sub -§5, as amended by PL 2011, c. 420, Pt. 27 
A, §11, is further amended to read:  28 
5.  Game of chance.  "Game of chance" means a game, contest, scheme or device in 29 
which:  30 
A.  A person stakes or risks something of value for the opportunity to win something 31 
of value;  32 
B.  The rules of operation or play require an  event the result of which is determined 33 
by chance, outside the control of the contestant or participant; and  34 
C.  Chance enters as an element that influences the outcome in a manner that cannot 35 
be eliminated through the application of skill.  36 
For the purpos es of this subsection, "an event the result of which is determined by 37 
chance" includes but is not limited to a shuffle of a deck of cards, a roll of a die or dice or 38 
a random drawing or generation of an object that may include, but is not limited to, a 39 
card, a die, a number or simulations of any of these. A shuffle of a deck of cards, a roll of 40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 684 - 128LR 2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  a die, a random drawing or generation of an object or some other event the result of 1 
which is determined by chance that is employed to determine impartially the init ial order 2 
of play in a game, contest, scheme or device does not alone make a game, contest, 3 
scheme or device a game of chance.  For purposes of this chapter, beano, bingo , a savings 4 
promotion raffle  and table games as defined in Title 8, section 1001, subs ection 43 -A are 5 
not games of chance.  6

A, §2, is amended to read:  8

chance.  11

B.  One or more of the chances is to be designated the winning chance; and  19

Chief of the State Police  The Gambling Control Unit  may issue a license to operate a 4 
game of chance  card g ame and certain tournament games  to an organization that submits 5 
a completed application as described in subsection 5 and has been founded, chartered or 6 
organized in this State for a period of not less than 2 consecutive years prior to applying 7 
for a licen se and is:  8 
A.  An agricultural society;  9 
B.  A bona fide nonprofit charitable, educational, political, civic, recreational, 10 
fraternal, patriotic or religious organization;  11 
C.  A volunteer fire department; or  12 
D.  An auxiliary of any of the organizations in p aragraphs A to C.  13 
2-A.  Registration.  The Gambling Control Unit may accept a registration from an 14 
eligible organization described in subsection 2 and other persons as specifically provided 15 
under section 1835 -A, section 1836, subsection 4 -B and section 183 7-A to conduct games 16 
of chance, raffles and charitable cribbage tournaments.  An eligible organization or 17 
person seeking to register to conduct a game of chance, raffle or charitable cribbage 18 
tournament shall register in the manner prescribed by the Gambli ng Control Unit and 19 
shall maintain records and reports in the same manner as described under section 1839, 20 
except that disposition of funds reports are not required to be submitted to the Gambling 21 
Control Unit but must be maintained in the same manner as o ther records.  22 
3.  Must be 18 years of age.   The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  23 
may not accept a registration to conduct a game of chance, a raffle or certain tournament 24 
games or accept  an application from or issue a license for card games  and certain 25 
tournament games  under this section to a person or  representative of an eligible 26 
organization who is not 18 years of age or older.  27 
4.  Municipal approval required.   An eligible organization described in subsection 28 
2 applying for a license to c onduct a card game of chance  and tournament games 29 
requiring a license  shall obtain written approval from the local governing authority where 30 
the game of chance  is to be operated or conducted.  This written approval must be 31 
submitted with the application to  the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  as 32 
described in subsection 5.  33 
5.  Application.   An eligible organization described in subsection 2 wishing  seeking 34 
to obtain a license  to operate or  conduct a card game of chance  or certain tournament 35 
games requiring a license  shall submit an application to the Chief of the State Police  36 
Gambling Control Unit .  The application must be in a form provided by the Chief of the 37 
State Police  Gambling Control Unit  and must be signed by a duly authorized officer o f 38 
the eligible organization. The application must include the full name and address of the 39 
organization, a full description of the card game of chance  or tournament game , the 40 
location where the card game or tournament game  is to be conducted and any other 41 
information determined necessary by the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  42 
for the issuance of a license to operate a card game of chance  or certain tournament 43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 686 - 128LR 2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  games , including but not limited to membership lists, bylaws and documentation show ing 1 
the organization's nonprofit status or charitable designation.  2 
6.  Multiple licenses.   The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may 3 
issue more than one license or registration  to conduct or operate a game of chance  4 
governed by this chapter  simultaneously to an eligible organization described in 5 
subsection 2.  Each game of chance  governed by this chapter  must have a separate 6 
license, the nature of which must be specified on the license.  7 
7.  Agricultural fairs.   Notwithstanding any provision in  this chapter to the contrary, 8 
in addition to games of chance, the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may 9 
issue a license  accept a registration  to conduct or operate games of chance known as 10 
"penny falls" or "quarter falls" at any agricultural  fair, as long as the net revenue from 11 
those games is retained by the licensed  registered  agricultural society.  12 
8.  Electronic video machines.   The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  13 
may issue a game of chance  license to operate an electronic video machine to any eligible 14 
organization described in subsection 2.  15 
A.  An electronic video machine licensed under this section may only be operated for 16 
the exclusive benefit of the licensee, except that up to 50% of the gross proceeds 17 
from the operation  of the machine may be paid to the distributor as a rental fee and 18 
for service and repair of the machine. Notwithstanding other provisions of this 19 
chapter, a licensee may rent an electronic video machine from a distributor.  20 
B.  No more than 5 electronic vi deo machines may be operated on the licensee's 21 
premises.  A separate games of chance license is required for the operation of each 22 
electronic video machine.  23 
C.  A licensee may operate an electronic video machine only on the licensee's 24 
premises.  25 
D.  Two or more licensees may not share the use of any premises for the operation of 26 
electronic video machines.  27 
E.  A distributor or employee of the distributor may not be a member of the licensed 28 
organization.  29 
F.  An electronic video machine licensed under this subs ection may not be operated 30 
in a manner that meets the definition of illegal gambling machine as described in 31 
Title 17 -A, section 952, subsection 5 -A. 32 
Sec. KKKKK -16.  17 MRSA §1834, as amended by PL 2013, c. 218, §1, is 33 
further amended to read:  34 
§1834.  Fees  35 
1.  Original application fee.   The original application for a license to operate a game 36 
of chance must be accompanied by a fee of $7.50. This is not a fee for a license and is not 37 
refundable.  38 
2.  Operation of games of chance.   Except for electronic video games and games of 39 
cards  as provided in this section, the registration  fee for a license  to operate a game of 40 
chance is $15 for each week computed on a Monday to Sunday basis or for a portion of a 41

issued for a calendar year is $700.  2

weekly or monthly licenses for the operation of games of chance.  Except for games of 4 
cards as provided in su bsection 4, licenses  Registration  to conduct any authorized game 5 
of chance may be issued for a period of up to 12 months on one application.  6

for each week computed on a Monday to Sunday basis or for a portion of a week.  The 9 
fee for a license issued for a calendar month is $60.  10 
The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may iss ue any combination of 11 
weekly or monthly licenses for the operation of electronic video machines.  A license or 12 
combination of licenses to operate an authorized electronic video machine may be issued 13 
for a period of up to 12 months.  14

of cards, when the organization charges no more than a $10 daily entry fee for 16 
participation in the games of cards and when no money or valuable thing other than the 17 
$10 daily entry fee is gamb led by any person in connection with the game of cards, is $30 18 
for each calendar year or portion of a calendar year.  For card games that are played by 19 
placing the maximum bet of $1 per hand or deal, the license fee is the same as provided 20 
in subsection 2  for a calendar month is $60 and the fee for licenses issued for a calendar 21 
year is $700 . 22 
5.  Distributors.   The fee for a license issued to a distributor is $625 for each 23 
calendar year or portion of a calendar year.  24 
6.  Printers.  The fee for a license issu ed to a printer is $15 for each calendar year or 25 
portion of a calendar year.  26

issued for a period of up to 12 months on one application.  Authority to conduct a game 28 
of chance,  a raffle or charitable cribbage tournament games pursuant to section 1836, 29 
subsection 4 -B may be granted for a period of up to 12 months on one registration.  30 
All fees required by this section must accompany the a registration or an  application 31 
for any lic ense issued by authority of this chapter.  32 
Fees submitted as license or registration  fees must be refunded if the license is not 33 
issued or the registration is not accepted .  Rebates may not be given for any unused 34 
license or registration  or portion of an un used license or registration .  If any license is 35 
suspended or revoked as provided by this chapter, fees paid for that license or registration  36 
may not be refunded.  37

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §1835.  Conduct card games  1 
1.  Wagers or entry fees for card games; exceptions.   The following limits apply to 2 
games of chance  a card game . 3 
A.  The maximum bet for a licensed game of chance including  card games  game  in 4 
which bets are placed  per hand or per deal is $1.  5 
B.  Licensed card games that award part or all of the entry fees paid to participate in 6 
the game as prize money and in which no money or thing of value is wagered except 7 
for the entry fee are limited to a $10 daily entry fee an d no more than 60 players at 8 
any one time at any one location.  9 
C.  If the licensee operates card games of chance  for less than 3 total days in a 10 
calendar year and contributes 100% of the gross revenue from those games of chance  11 
to charity, the amount wager ed must be limited to:  12 
(1)  A $1 daily entry fee;  13 
(2)  Fifty cents per game; or  14 
(3)  Twenty -five cents per card received.  15 
Prior to play of the game, the licensee shall determine which of the limits in 16 
subparagraphs (1), (2) and (3) is to be used and shall post the limit where the game is 17 
conducted . 18 
2.  Games conducted by members and bartenders of licensee only.   A card game 19 
of chance  licensed pursuant to this chapter must be operated and conducted for the 20 
exclusive benefit of the licensee and must be operat ed and conducted only by duly 21 
authorized members of the licensee or by persons employed by the licensee as bartenders, 22 
except that nonmembers employed by the licensee as bartenders may not operate or 23 
conduct any card game of chance  permitted under subsecti on 5, paragraph B.  The 24 
requirements of this subsection do not apply to any agricultural society licensed to 25 
operate a card game of chance . 26 
3.  Games conducted at agricultural fair by members of the agricultural society 27 
or a bona fide nonprofit.  Games of chance  Card games  operated and conducted solely 28 
by members of an agricultural society or card games of chance  operated and conducted 29 
by members of bona fide nonprofit organizations on the grounds of the agricultural 30 
society and during the annual fair of th e agricultural society may use cash, tickets, tokens 31 
or other devices approved by the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  by rule.  32 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, the tickets, tokens or other devices 33 
approved by the Chief o f the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  must be unique to the 34 
agricultural society and may be in denominations of 25¢, 50¢ or $1.  The tickets, tokens 35 
or devices approved by the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may be sold 36 
and redeemed only  by a person who has been a member or active volunteer of the 37 
agricultural society for at least 2 fair seasons.  The agricultural society has the burden of 38 
proof for demonstrating the qualification of members or active volunteers.  39 
An agricultural society t hat uses tokens shall provide records and reports as required by 40 
section 1839.  41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 689 - 128LR2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  4.  Persons under 18 years of age.  Except as provided in this subsection, a  A 1 
licensee, game owner or operator may not permit a person under 18 years of age to take 2 
part in a card game of chance, and a person under 18 years of age may not sell chances, 3 
except in relation to charitable, religious or recognized youth associations .  4 
Notwithstanding any rule to the contrary, upon receiving an application on a form 5 
provided by the Ch ief of the State Police and a determination by the chief that a game of 6 
chance licensed to be conducted at a festival -style event is designed to attract players 7 
under 18 years of age and awards a nonmonetary prize valued at less than $10 for every 8 
chance p layed, the chief may permit:  9 
A.  Persons under 18 years of age to conduct or operate the game of chance; and  10 
B.  Persons under 18 years of age to play the game of chance without being 11 
accompanied by an adult.  12 
Nothing in this subsection permits games of cha nce to be operated without a license.  13 
5.  Location.   A license issued pursuant to this section must specify the location 14 
where the organization may operate the licensed card game of chance .  A licensee may 15 
not operate card games of chance  in more than one location at the same time.  16 
A.  An agricultural society or a bona fide nonprofit organization may operate a card 17 
game of chance  on the grounds of an agricultural society and during the annual fair of 18 
the agricultural society.  19 
B.  No more than one licensee m ay operate a card game of chance  at a time on the 20 
same premises.  In any room where a licensed card game of chance  is being 21 
conducted, there must be at least one member of the licensee present in that room for 22 
every 2 nonmembers who are present.  That memb er must have been a member of the 23 
licensee for at least one year.  A member of the licensee, either directly or through 24 
another member or guest, may not stake or risk something of value in the licensee's 25 
card game of chance  unless the member has been a mem ber of the licensee for at 26 
least 14 days not including the day of admission into membership.  27 
A bona fide nonprofit organization may operate a licensed card game of chance  to which 28 
the general public has access once every 3 months for a period not to exceed  3 29 
consecutive days.  The licensed card game of chance  may be operated at any location 30 
described in the license and may be conducted only by members of the licensee.  This 31 
subsection does not apply to raffles conducted in accordance with section 1837.  32 
6.  Door prizes.   Distribution of tickets to an event upon which appear details 33 
concerning any prize to be given away as a result of a drawing is a game of chance within 34 
the meaning of this chapter; a distribution of tickets containing only the words "Door 35 
Prize," without further description, is excluded from the provisions of this chapter, as 36 
long as no promotional materials or presentations, written or oral, describe the door prize.  37 
7.  "Donation" not to provide an exclusion.  The word "donation" printed on a  38 
ticket does not exclude the sponsoring organization from complying with this chapter.  39 
8.  Wager limit exception.  Notwithstanding subsection 1, an organization that is 40 
licensed to conduct games of chance in accordance with this chapter is permitted to 41 
accept wagers up to $50 per hand for a poker run.  The organization must inform the 42 
Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  30 days in advance of the date when the 43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 690 - 128LR 2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  organization intends to conduct a poker run with an increased wager limit.  An 1 
organiza tion is limited to 2 poker run events per calendar year in which wagers up to $50 2 
per hand are permitted.  For the purposes of this subsection, "poker run" means a game of 3 
chance using playing cards that requires a player to travel from one geographic loca tion 4 
to another in order to play the game.  5

Sec. KKKKK -21.  17 MRSA §1836, sub -§4-A, as enacted by PL 2015, c. 163, 20 
§1, is am ended to read:  21 
4-A.  Exception for super cribbage tournament.  Notwithstanding any provision of 22 
this section to the contrary, the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may 23 
issue up to 3 licenses per year for the conduct of a super cribbage tourna ment.  For the 24 
purposes of this subsection, "cribbage" means a card game that uses a board and pegs to 25 
keep score and of which the characteristic feature is a crib into which players discard 26 
cards from their dealt hand to create a crib of 4 cards unseen by  other players that will be 27 
ultimately part of the dealer's hand.  The license fee for a super cribbage tournament is 28 
$75.  A super cribbage tournament must be conducted in the same manner as prescribed 29 
for a tournament game by this section except as follo ws. 30 
A.  The super cribbage tournament may be conducted by a nationally chartered 31 
organization that organizes tournament -style cribbage games and that is exempt from 32 
taxation under the United States Internal Revenue Code, Section 501(c)(3) so long as 33 
the pr incipal organizer has been a member of that organization for a period of not less 34 
than 3 years.  35 
B.  The minimum number of players required is 50.  36 
C.  The maximum entry fee allowed is $100 per player.  37 
D.  The super cribbage tournament need not be held on pr emises owned by the 38 
licensee.  39 
E.  The super cribbage tournament may be conducted over a period of up to 72 hours.  40 
F.  Notwithstanding subsection 2, 50% of the proceeds of the super cribbage 41 
tournament after prizes are paid must be paid to a bona fide chari table organization, 42

Sec. KKKKK -22.  17 MRSA §1836, sub -§4-B is enacted to read:  4 
4-B.  Charitable cribbage tournament.  The Gambling Control Unit shall accept a 5 
registration for a cribbage tournament to be conducted as prescribed by this subsection.  6 
For the purposes of this section, "cribbage" means a card game that uses a board and p egs 7 
to keep score and of which the characteristic feature is a crib into which players discard 8 
cards from their dealt hand to create a crib of 4 cards unseen by other players that will be 9 
ultimately part of the dealer's hand. In a cribbage tournament, winn ers are determined by 10 
a process of elimination.  A cribbage tournament may extend beyond a calendar day.  A 11 
person may operate a cribbage tournament as registered by the Gambling Control Unit if 12 
the operator:  13 
A.  Is a restaurant licensed in accordance with  Title 22, chapter 562 or a manufacturer 14 
licensed under Title 28 -A, section 1355 -A who offers complimentary samples or 15 
samples for a charge to the public at the licensee's manufacturing facility.  For the 16 
purposes of this subsection, "restaurant" means a r eputable place operated by 17 
responsible persons of good reputation that is regularly used for the purpose of 18 
providing food for the public and that has adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining 19 
room equipment and capacity for preparing and serving suitable f ood for the public;  20 
B.  Limits play to the location of the licensed establishment and to patrons of the 21 
licensed establishment who are 21 years of age or older; and  22 
C.  Charges an entry fee not to exceed $25 per person for participation in the cribbage 23 
tournament.  Notwithstanding section 1838, all entry fees must be awarded as prizes 24 
to winners of the tournament for which the entry fees were paid, except that the 25 
operator may donate all or a portion of the entry fees to a charitable organization.  An 26 
opera tor may not charge a fee except for the entry fee and may not receive any 27 
portion of the proceeds from the operation of the cribbage tournament.  28

Sec. KKKKK -25.  17 MRSA §1837 -A is enacted to read:  40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 694 - 128LR 2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §1837 -A.  Raffles  1 
1.  Registration required.  Unless otherwise specified by this section, a person or 2 
organization may not conduct a  raffle without registering with the Gambling Control 3 
Unit.  4 
2.  Raffle with a prize of $1,000 or less.  A person or organization is not required to 5 
register with the Gambling Control Unit to conduct a raffle in which the total value of the 6 
prize offered to  the holder of the winning chance does not exceed $1,000.  If the raffle is 7 
conducted in a manner in which there are multiple winning chances, the total value of all 8 
prizes offered may not exceed a value of $1,000.  9 
3.  Raffle with a noncash prize of $1,001  to $10,000.  A person or organization may 10 
conduct a raffle in which the total value of the prize offered to the winning chance is 11 
greater than $1,001 and does not exceed $10,000 upon the acceptance of a registration by 12 
the Gambling Control Unit.  The Gamb ling Control Unit may not accept a registration for 13 
a raffle under this subsection unless the registration states a verifiable charitable purpose 14 
for which the proceeds of the raffle are dedicated to benefit.  If the raffle is conducted in a 15 
manner in whic h there are multiple winning chances, the total value of all prizes offered 16 
may not exceed a value of $10,000.  A prize offered for a raffle conducted under this 17 
subsection may not be in the form of cash and may not be exchanged for cash.  18 
4.  Raffle with a  noncash prize up to $75,000 conducted by eligible organization.  19 
An eligible organization as described in section 1832, subsection 2 may conduct a raffle 20 
in which the total value of the prize offered to the winning chance does not exceed 21 
$75,000 upon the acceptance of a registration by the Gambling Control Unit.  The 22 
registration must state a verifiable charitable purpose for which the proceeds of the raffle 23 
are dedicated to benefit.  If the raffle is conducted in a manner in which there are multiple 24 
winni ng chances, the total value of all prizes offered may not exceed a value of $75,000.  25 
A prize for a raffle conducted under this subsection may not be in the form of cash and 26 
may not be exchanged for cash.  An eligible organization may not conduct more than  one 27 
raffle under this subsection in a 12 -month period.  28 
5.  Raffle conducted by persons 18 years of age or older; exception.  Raffle 29 
chances or tickets may not be sold by a person under 18 years of age, except for raffles 30 
conducted under subsections 2 and 3 designed to benefit activities of children at an event 31 
generally attended by persons under 18 years of age.  32

Sec. KKKKK -27.  17 MRSA §1839, as enacted by PL 2009, c. 487, Pt. A, §2, is 25 
amended to read:  26 
§1839.  Records and reports  27 
1.  Records required.   Each licensee or registrant  shall keep a record of all financial 28 
transactions involving games of chance  operated under each license granted to the 29 
licensee  this chapter .  The treasurer of the licensee or another officer designated by the 30 
treasurer is responsible for maintaining those records.   The records must include an exact 31 
account of all gross revenue from the games, an itemization of all allowable expenses, 32 
including, but not limited to, the cost of prizes, printing, licenses and administration, and 33 
the disposition of all proceeds, including, but not limited to, all gifts, grants and payments 34 
to any person, firm, corporation, association or organization for any purpose whatsoever.  35 
All financial records involving games of chance  operated under this chapter  must be 36 
separate and distinguishable from other records of the organization.  Revenue from  more 37 
than one game of chance  operated under this chapter  may be entered into one account.  38 
2.  Records required for licensee or registrant employing tokens.   If a licensee or 39 
registrant  employs tokens to account for revenue from games of chance  operated un der 40 
this chapter  and if the licensee or registrant  maintains direct control over the sale and 41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 696 - 128LR 2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  redemption of the tokens and keeps accurate records of all tokens used, then the chief  1 
Gambling Control Unit  may by rule alter or reduce the record -keeping requir ements of 2 
subsection 1 to the extent that a licensee's  the use of tokens renders those records 3 
unnecessary for adequate control of the licensee's or registrant's  games.  4 
3.  Disposition of funds reports.   Within 10 business days after the last day of any 5 
period during which a licensed game of chance  under this chapter  is conducted with other 6 
than an annual license or within 10 business days after the end of each calendar month 7 
during which a licensed game of chance is conducted with an annual license , the li censee 8 
shall file with the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  a disposition of funds 9 
form prescribed and furnished by the Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit , 10 
detailing for the period the total receipts and expenditures of the game  and the disposition 11 
of funds.  Every statement must be made under oath by an officer of the licensee or by the 12 
member in charge of the conduct of the game.  A registrant who conducts games under 13 
this chapter shall maintain records of disposition of funds,  which must be made available 14 
to the Gambling Control Unit upon request.  15 
4.  Disposition of funds reports from registrant using tokens.   If tokens are 16 
employed to account for revenue from games of chance  operated under this chapter , then 17 
the licensee  regis trant shall maintain a  report of the number of tokens sold, the number 18 
redeemed and the disposition of funds from the proceeds of sale in addition to such other 19 
information as the chief  Gambling Control Unit  may require under subsection 3.  20 
5.  Records main tained for 3 years.   Every licensee or registrant  that has conducted 21 
a game of chance  under this chapter  shall maintain and keep for a period of 3 years 22 
reports as may be necessary to substantiate the records and reports required by this 23 
section or by the rules adopted under this chapter.  24 
6.  Location.  All records maintained by a licensee or registrant  pursuant to this 25 
section and pursuant to the rules adopted under this chapter must be kept and maintained 26 
on the premises where the game of chance  has been c onducted or at the primary business 27 
office of the licensee or registrant , which must be designated by the licensee in the license 28 
application or the registrant in the registration .  These records must be open to inspection 29 
by the Chief of the State Police or the chief's representative  Gambling Control Unit , and a 30 
licensee or registrant  may not refuse the Chief of the State Police or the chief's 31 
representative  Gambling Control Unit  permission to inspect or audit the records.  Refusal 32 
to permit inspection or audit of the records does not constitute a crime under this chapter 33 
but constitutes grounds for revocation of license or registration . 34 
Sec. KKKKK -28.  17 MRSA §1840, as enacted by PL 2009, c. 487, Pt. A, §2, is 35 
amended to read:  36 
§1840.  Distributors; record s and reports  37 
1.  Printers licensed.   A printer in the State may not print materials to be used in the 38 
conduct of a licensed game of chance unless licensed by the Chief of the State Police.  A 39 
printer licensed under this section may act as a distributor wi thout having to be licensed 40 
as a distributor as long as neither the printer nor anyone on the printer's behalf acts as a 41 
seller for services connected with a game of chance outside of the confines of the printer's 42 
premises described in that printer's licen se.  If that printer or someone else acts as a seller 43 
for the printer's services in connection with a game of chance outside of the premises 44

 Page 697 - 128LR2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  described on that printer's license, either that printer or any person or persons acting on 1 
that printer's behalf m ust be licensed as a distributor under subsection 2.  2 
The applicant for a printer's license, or, if the applicant is a firm, corporation, association 3 
or other organization, its resident manager, superintendent or official representative shall 4 
file an applic ation with the Chief of the State Police on a form provided by the Chief of 5 
the State Police.  The Chief of the State Police shall furnish to each applicant a current 6 
copy of this chapter and the rules adopted under section 1843 and to each licensee a copy  7 
of any changes or additions to this chapter and the rules adopted under section 1843.  8 
2.  Distributors licensed.   A distributor may not sell, lease, market or otherwise 9 
distribute gambling apparatus or implements unless licensed by the Chief of the State 10 
Police  Gambling Control Unit , except that a license is not required for the sale, marketing 11 
or distribution of raffle tickets when the holder of the winning chance receives something 12 
of value worth less than $10,000.  13 
A nonresident manufacturer or distribut or of gambling apparatus or implements doing 14 
business in the State must have an agent in this State who is licensed as a distributor.  A 15 
distributor may not sell, market or otherwise distribute gambling apparatus or implements 16 
to a person or organization, except to persons or eligible  organizations described under 17 
section 1832, subsection 2  licensed or registered  to operate or conduct games of chance  18 
under section 1832, licensed  this chapter or registered  to conduct a special raffle under 19 
section 1837, subs ection 2 or eligible to conduct a raffle pursuant to section 1837, 20 
subsection 1  1837 -A.  A distributor may not lease or loan or otherwise distribute free of 21 
charge any gambling apparatus or implements to an organization eligible to operate a 22 
game of chance  under this chapter , except that a distributor may lease gambling apparatus 23 
or implements to an agricultural society licensed  registered  to operate games of chance on 24 
the grounds of the agricultural society and during the annual fair of the agricultural 25 
society as long as the distributor does not charge the agricultural society an amount in 26 
excess of 50% of the gross revenue from any licensed  game of chance  conducted under 27 
this chapter . 28 
A licensee or registrant  shall acquire gambling apparatus and implement s from a 29 
distributor licensed under this section, unless the gambling apparatus or implements are 30 
printed, manufactured or constructed by the licensed organization.  At no time may any 31 
licensee print, manufacture or construct any gambling apparatus or impl ements for 32 
distribution to any other licensee.  The applicant for a distributor's license , or, if the 33 
applicant is a firm, corporation, association or other organization, its resident manager, 34 
superintendent or official representative shall file an applica tion with the Chief of the 35 
State Police  Gambling Control Unit  on a form provided by the Chief of the State Police  36 
Gambling Control Unit .  The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  shall 37 
furnish to each applicant a current copy of this chapter and  the rules adopted under 38 
section 1843 and to each licensee a copy of any changes or additions to this chapter and 39 
the rules adopted under section 1843.  40 
3.  Sales agreements.  A distributor shall forward to the Chief of the State Police  41 
Gambling Control Uni t, prior to delivery of any gambling machine to the purchaser, a 42 
copy of all sales agreements, sales contracts or any other agreements involving the sale of 43 
any gambling machine.  The terms of the sales contract must include, but are not limited 44 
to, the na me of seller, name of purchaser, address of seller, address of purchaser, 45

 Page 698 - 128LR 2175(02) -1

Any chan ge, modification or alteration of these agreements must be reported to the Chief 4

implement; serial number, model name or number of the gambling apparatus or 22 
implement; and all  prices and payments for the lease.  Each lease must be for a specific 23 
period of time no longer than the duration of the annual fair of that lessee, and each 24 
gambling apparatus must have its own separate lease.  Gambling apparatus or implements 25 
leased unde r this section:  26 
A.  May be operated only for the exclusive benefit of the agricultural society, except 27 
that the agricultural society may pay a distributor up to 50% of gross gaming revenue 28 
in accordance with subsection 2; and  29 
B.  Must bear the name and add ress of the distributor.  30

or printer  has distributed equipment and the dates of the distribution;  34

name and number; and  36

may be necessary to substantiate the reports required by this section or by the rules 40 
adopte d under this chapter.  The records must be open to inspection, and a licensee or 41 
registrant  may not refuse the Chief of the State Police or the chief's representative  42

§1842.  Investigations and actions on licenses and registrations; evidence  10

violations of this chapter or the rules adopted pursuant to section 1843.  13

contempt.  The court shall, in a summary manner, hear the evidence and, if it is such 20 
as to warrant the court in doing s o, punish that witness in the same manner and to the 21

the process of the Superior Court; and  23

bartender as required by section 1835, subsection 2 and section 1835 -A, subsection 2 .  36

Gambling Control Unit .  The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may 38

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  registrant's  receipt of the notice, of the duration of the suspension or revocation and of the 1 
right to a hearing pursuant to this subsection.  The applicant or, licensee , person 2 
registering or registrant  has the right to request a hearing before the Commissioner of 3 
Public Safety or the commissioner's designee.  Upon the applicant's or licensee's  request 4 
for a hearing, the Commissioner of Public Safety shall provide a hearing.  The hearing 5 
must comply with the Maine Administrative Procedure Act.  The p urpose of the hearing 6 
is to determine whether a preponderance of the evidence establishes that the applicant, 7 
person registering,  applicant's or registering person's  agent or employee or the licensee , 8 
registrant  or licensee's or registrant's  agent or emplo yee violated a provision of this 9 
chapter or Title 17 -A, chapter 39.  A request for a hearing may not be made any later than 10 
10 days after the applicant or, licensee , person registering or registrant  is notified of the 11 
proposed denial, suspension or revocat ion.  The suspension or revocation must be stayed 12 
pending the hearing; the hearing may not be held any later than 30 days after the date the 13 
commissioner receives the request unless otherwise agreed by the parties or continued 14 
upon request of a party for c ause shown.  15

registration  is immediately suspended or revoked by the Chief of the State Police  17 
Gambling Control Unit  pursuant to subsection 3, paragraph C must be notified in  writing 18 
of the duration of the suspension or revocation and the licensee's or registrant's  right to 19 
request a hearing before the Commissioner of Public Safety or the commissioner's 20 
designee.  Upon the licensee's or registrant's  request for a hearing, the Commissioner of 21 
Public Safety shall provide a hearing.  The hearing must comply with the Maine 22 
Administrative Procedure Act.  The purpose of the hearing is to determine whether a 23 
preponderance of the evidence establishes that the licensee or, the registran t, the 24 
licensee's agent or employee or the registrant's agent or employee  violated section 1832, 25 
subsection 8, paragraph C; section 1841, subsection 2; or a provision of Title 17 -A, 26 
chapter 39.  A request for a hearing may not be made any later than 48 hou rs after the 27 
licensee or registrant  is notified of the suspension or revocation.  A hearing may not be 28 
held any later than 10 days after the date the commissioner receives the request.  29

Gambling Control Unit . 37

Public Safety or the city or town fi re inspectors of the municipality in which the licensed 40 
or registered  game is being conducted to enter and inspect the licensed  premises where 41 
the game is being conducted . 42 
Sec. KKKKK -30.  17 MRSA §1843, as enacted by PL 2009, c. 487, Pt. A, §2, is 43 
amended to read:  44 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 702 - 128LR 2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §1843.  Rules  1 
The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  may adopt routine technical 2 
rules pursuant to Title 5, chapter 375, subchapter 2 -A necessary for the administration 3 
and enforcement of this chapter and for the licensing , registrati on, conduct and operation 4 
of games of chance  governed by this chapter .  The Chief of the State Police  Gambling 5 
Control Unit  may regulate, supervise and exercise general control over the operation of 6 
such games. In establishing such rules, the Chief of the State Police must  Gambling 7 
Control Unit shall , in addition to the standards set forth in other provisions of this 8 
chapter, set forth conduct, conditions and activity considered undesirable, including:  9 
1.  Fraud.  The practice of any fraud or deception upon a participant in a game of 10 
chance  governed by this chapter ; 11 
2.  Unsafe premises.  The conduct of a game of chance  governed by this chapter  in or 12 
at premises that may be unsafe due to fire hazard or other such conditions;  13 
3.  Advertising and solicitation.  Advertising that is obscene or solicitation on a 14 
public way of persons to participate in a game of chance  governed by this chapter ; 15 
4.  Organized crime.  Infiltration of organized crime into the operation of games of 16 
chance  governed by this chapter  or into th e printing or distributing of gambling materials;  17 
5.  Disorderly persons.  Presence of disorderly persons in a location where a game of 18 
chance  governed by this chapter  is being conducted;  19 
6.  Leasing of equipment.   Leasing of equipment by a licensee or regi strant  used in 20 
the operation of games of chance  governed by this chapter  not in accordance with this 21 
chapter; and  22 
7.  Bona fide nonprofit organization.  The establishment of organizations that exist 23 
primarily to operate games of chance  governed by this chap ter and do not have a bona 24 
fide nonprofit charitable, educational, political, civic, recreational, fraternal, patriotic, 25 
religious or public safety purpose.  26 
The Chief of the State Police  Gambling Control Unit  shall provide a mechanism for 27 
individuals and b usinesses to request a determination from the State Police  Gambling 28 
Control Unit  as to whether a particular game, contest, scheme or device qualifies as a 29 
game of chance or a game of skill.  30

Sec. KKKKK -33.  Authority to administer and enforce, and make 11 
necessary technical changes to, existing games of chance rules and 12 
regulati ons.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law, games of chance rules that 13 
have been adopted by the Department of Public Safety, Bureau of State Police pursuant to 14 
the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 17, chapter 62 may be administered and enforced by the 15 
Gambling Control Unit upon the effective date of this Act. To the extent necessary to 16 
make such rules consistent with the intent of this Act, the Gambling Control Unit may 17 
make technical amendments to the rules and regulations without having to engage in 18 
rulemaking pursuant to the Maine Administrative Procedure Act.  19

Sec. LLLLL -1.  25 MRSA §2396, sub -§7, as amended by PL 2003, c. 42, §1, is 21 
further amended to read:  22 
7.  Other duties.  The performance of such other duties as are set forth in this and 23 
other sections of the statutes and as may be conferred or imposed from time to time by 24 
law.  The State Fire Marshal, the State Fire Marshal's deputy and investigators appointed 25 
under this Title shall carry out those functions that the Commissioner of Publi c Safety 26 
may direct and in so doing have the same enforcement powers and duties throughout the 27 
State as sheriffs have in their respective counties.  A public safety inspector for the 28 
purpose of enforcing section 2452, relating to statewide enforcement powe rs of the 29 
National Fire Protection Association No. 101, Life Safety Code, has the right to execute 30 
or serve criminal and civil violation process against offenders who violate the National 31 
Fire Protection Association No. 101, Life Safety Code.  32
