Sec. VVVVV -6.  20-A MRSA c. 123 is enacted to read:  29 
CHAPTER 123  30 
SCHOOL MANAGEMENT AN D LEADERSHIP CENTERS  31 
§3801.  General provisions  32 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise indic ates, the 33 
following terms have the following meanings.  34 
A.  "Municipality" means a city, town or organized plantation.  35 
B.  "School management and leadership center" means a multiservice agency 36 
established and operated exclusively for the purposes of develop ing, managing and 37 
providing services or programs to 2 or more members pursuant to section 3802, 38 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 707 - 128LR2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  subsection 2 and may include associate members pursuant to section 3802, subsection 1 
3.  A "school management and leadership center" is a political subdivision p ursuant 2 
to section 3802, subsection 7.  3 
2.  Establishment.  A school administrative unit as described in section 3802, 4 
subsection 2 may become a member of a school management and leadership center 5 
through an interlocal agreement pursuant to Title 30 -A, chap ter 115 and the agreement 6 
may include associate members as described in section 3802, subsection 3.  7 
3.  Interlocal agreement.  An interlocal agreement establishing a school 8 
management and leadership center must include the structure and governance of the 9 
school management and leadership center and its functions, programs and services.  10 
A.  An interlocal agreement must include the specifications required pursuant to Title 11 
30-A, section 2203, subsection 2 and a description of:  12 
(1)  The school management and le adership center board composition, election or 13 
appointment of officers, board member terms and method of voting;  14 
(2)  An approval process for a new school administrative unit to join the school 15 
management and leadership center;  16 
(3)  An approval process for  an existing member to transfer to another school 17 
management and leadership center;  18 
(4)  The process for determining the sharing of costs for and the assessments of 19 
or payments to the school management and leadership center;  20 
(5)  The budget process that re quires a school management and leadership center 21 
budget be adopted by a date established in order to meet local school 22 
administrative unit budget deadlines.  The budget process must include a 23 
contingency plan for a budget failure and must be in the cost ce nter summary 24 
budget format pursuant to section 1485;  25 
(6)  The process for a balanced budget as required by section 3802, subsection 10 26 
and the method of determining the return of any excess funds to the members of 27 
the school management and leadership cente r; and  28 
(7)  The process for the disposition of indebtedness and property including by 29 
sale or lease, transferred to or from or administered by the school management 30 
and leadership center.  31 
B.  An interlocal agreement may include but is not limited to a desc ription of the 32 
following:  33 
(1)  The approval process for the formation of a school management and 34 
leadership center;  35 
(2)  Any associate members, the process for including associate members and 36 
their roles in the school management and leadership center;  37 
(3)  The process to authorize the school management and leadership center to 38 
borrow funds for school construction purposes including bonds and notes;  39 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 708 - 128LR 2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (4)  The process to approve the purchase or lease of buildings or land by the 1 
school management and leadership  center;  2 
(5)  The process by which a school management and leadership center may 3 
establish, maintain and expend funds from a reserve fund or contingency fund;  4 
(6)  The process of hiring an executive director for the school management and 5 
leadership center;  and 6 
(7)  A transition plan to move authorized programs and services from a member 7 
to the school management and leadership center.  8 
An interlocal agreement cannot transfer a school administrative unit's responsibility for 9 
providing the opportunity of a free  public education to each of its students or a free, 10 
appropriate education to each of its students with a disability as required by this Title or 11 
by federal law.  12 
4.  Duties of school management and leadership center.  A school management 13 
and leadership cen ter's functions, programs and services may include but are not limited 14 
to the following:  15 
A.  Accounting, payroll and financial management services and procurement;  16 
B.  Transportation, transportation routing and vehicle maintenance;  17 
C.  Reporting functions;  18 
D.  Special education programs and administration;  19 
E.  Gifted and talented programs and administration;  20 
F.  Alternative education programs and administration;  21 
G.  Substitute teachers and staff augmentation;  22 
H.  Technology and technology support;  23 
I.  Food service planning and purchasing;  24 
J.  Energy management and facilities maintenance;  25 
K.  Regional school leadership academies;  26 
L.  Staff training and professional development;  27 
M.  Shared educational programs or staff;  28 
N.  Shared support service programs;  29 
O.  Educational programs such as summer school, extended school year, tutoring, 30 
advanced placement and other programs that serve students and improve student 31 
achievement;  32 
P.  Shared extracurricular or cocurricular programs; and  33 
Q.  Superintendent services.  34 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 709 - 128LR2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §3802.  School management and leadership center authorized  1 
A school management and leadership center shall provide administrative and 2 
education functions in accordance with this chapter and shall function as an extension of 3 
the member school administrative u nits and associate members of the school management 4 
and leadership center.  A member school administrative unit of the school management 5 
and leadership center cannot transfer the responsibility for providing the opportunity of a 6 
free public education to ea ch of its students or a free, appropriate education to each of its 7 
students with a disability as required by this Title or by federal law.  8 
1.  Geographic boundaries.  The commissioner shall determine 9 to 12 geographic 9 
areas for the establishment of each s chool management and leadership center.  10 
Membership in a particular school management and leadership center does not require the 11 
member to be physically located in the school management and leadership center's 12 
geographic boundary.  13 
2.  Members.  Members in a school management and leadership center must be 14 
determined by interlocal agreement pursuant to Title 30 -A, chapter 115 and may include 15 
the following types of school administrative units:  16 
A.  Community school districts pursuant to chapter 105;  17 
B.  Municip al school units pursuant to chapter 111;  18 
C.  Regional school units pursuant to chapter 103 -A; 19 
D.  School administrative districts pursuant to chapter 103; and  20 
E.  Schools established on tribal lands pursuant to Title 30, chapter 601.  21 
3.  Associate members.   Associate members for a school management and leadership 22 
center may include the following through a contractual agreement or memorandum of 23 
understanding with the members of the school management and leadership center:  24 
A.  Career and technical education r egions pursuant to chapter 313, subchapter 4;  25 
B.  Public charter schools as defined in chapter 112;  26 
C.  Providers of child development services pursuant to chapter 303;  27 
D.  Magnet schools pursuant to chapters 312 and 312 -A; 28 
E.  The Maine Educational Center  for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing and the 29 
Governor Baxter School for the Deaf pursuant to chapter 304;  30 
F.  Providers of education in the unorganized territory pursuant to chapter 119; or  31 
G.  Municipalities and counties pursuant to Title 30 -A. 32 
4.  Provision  of services to or from other public entities or nonprofit entities.   A 33 
school management and leadership center may provide services to or purchase services 34 
from other types of political subdivisions, public entities or nonprofit organizations or 35 
associati ons. 36 
5.  Purchase of services from another school management and leadership center.  37 
A member of a school management and leadership center may purchase services from 38 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 710 - 128LR 2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  another school management and leadership center if not provided by the member’s school 1 
management and leadership center.  2 
6.  Validation.  A school management and leadership center authorized and 3 
organized under this chapter is validated, confirmed, approved and declared legal in all 4 
respects, notwithstanding any defect or irregularity that may have occurred in the 5 
organization of the school management and leadership center or in the selection of the 6 
board of that school management and leadership center.  7 
7.  Political subdivision.  A school management and leadership center is a political 8 
subdivis ion within the meaning of Title 5, section 19002, subsection 6 and a quasi - 9 
municipal corporation within the meaning of Title 30 -A, section 5701, and all the 10 
provisions of those sections apply to it. Notwithstanding Title 30 -A, section 2203, 11 
subsection 8, p aragraph B, the members of a school management and leadership center 12 
may delegate eminent domain power to the school management and leadership center by 13 
agreement. A school management and leadership center is considered a tax -exempt 14 
governmental entity for  the purposes of Title 36, section 1760, subsection 2.  15 
8.  Executive director.  A school management and leadership center shall employ an 16 
executive director, and the interlocal agreement under section 3801, subsection 3 must 17 
specify that the executive dire ctor shall administer, in compliance with this chapter, the 18 
provisions of the interlocal agreement in the school management and leadership center.  19 
9.  Personnel.  The executive director of a school management and leadership center 20 
may employ a chief financ ial officer and may employ additional staff necessary to 21 
administer the functions assigned to the school management and leadership center 22 
through the provisions of the interlocal agreement under section 3801, subsection 3.  23 
10.  Balanced budget.  A school m anagement and leadership center must have a 24 
balanced budget and return excess funds to the members as prescribed by the interlocal 25 
agreement under section 3801, subsection 3.  26 
11.  Authority to borrow, expend and accept funds.  A school management and 27 
leade rship center may:  28 
A.  Borrow funds in anticipation of a member’s payment of its share of the school 29 
management and leadership center budget. Such borrowing:  30 
(1)  Must be repaid within one year; and  31 
(2)  May not at any time exceed 3/4 of the school manageme nt and leadership 32 
center's annual approved budget;  33 
B.  Expend available funds to pay debt service, security and maintenance costs; and  34 
C.  Accept and expend funds from state, federal and other sources and expend those 35 
funds on behalf of the members.  36 
12.  Bonding authority.  A school management and leadership center may issue 37 
bonds and notes for school construction purposes. For purposes of this section, "school 38 
construction purposes" includes minor capital costs relating to maintenance of a school's 39 
physica l plant. The school management and leadership center board shall decide whether 40 
the issuance of bonds or notes by the school management and leadership center for school 41 
construction purposes is necessary. The board shall determine whether the issuance of 42 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 711 - 128LR2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  bonds or notes is authorized, and, if so, the board shall issue the bonds or notes and 1 
administer the proceeds of, and the payment of principal of and interest on, those bonds 2 
or notes after issuance. A school management and leadership center may issue bond s and 3 
notes for school construction purposes only under the provisions of the interlocal 4 
agreement under section 3801, subsection 3.  5 
13.  Withdrawal from school management and leadership center.  If a single 6 
school administrative unit applies to withdraw, it must demonstrate to the commissioner 7 
that as a result of the school administrative unit's withdrawing that there will be no 8 
increase in costs or decrease in student programs and services for the withdrawing school 9 
administrative unit and for any of the remaining member school administrative units of 10 
the school management and leadership center.  11 
14.  Dissolution of school management and leadership center.  A school 12 
management and leadership center may not be dissolved unless it applies to the 13 
commissioner for approval and:  14 
A.  All member school administrative units apply to transfer to another school 15 
management and leadership center; or  16 
B.  If all the member school administrative units of a school management and 17 
leadership center apply to dissolve the schoo l management and leadership center, 18 
they demonstrate to the commissioner that there will be no increase in costs or 19 
decrease in student programs and services for any of the member school 20 
administrative units of the school management and leadership center.  21 
15.  Reporting requirements.  A school management and leadership center must 22 
meet state and federal reporting requirements on behalf of each member school 23 
administrative unit.  24 
§3803.  Oversight  25 
The commissioner shall provide oversight of the school managem ent and leadership 26 
centers, and this oversight must include the following.  27 
1.  Data collection; monitoring.  The commissioner or the commissioner's designee 28 
is responsible for collecting, analyzing and reporting data from school management and 29 
leadership c enters. The commissioner or the commissioner's designee shall monitor the 30 
performance and legal compliance of the school management and leadership centers, 31 
including collecting and analyzing data to support ongoing evaluation of the school 32 
management and l eadership centers.  33 
2.  Notification of unsatisfactory performance or compliance.  If a school 34 
management and leadership center’s performance or legal compliance appears 35 
unsatisfactory, the commissioner shall promptly provide written notice to the school 36 
management and leadership center and its members of perceived problems and provide 37 
reasonable opportunity for the school management and leadership center to remedy the 38 
problems.  The school management and leadership center shall provide the commissioner 39 
a corrective action plan to remedy the problems.  40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 712 - 128LR 2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §3804.  Audit  1 
A school management and leadership center shall adhere to generally accepted 2 
accounting principles and shall annually engage an external auditor to do an independent 3 
audit of the school management and leadership center's finances. The school management 4 
and leadership center shall submit the audit to its members and to the department. The 5 
audit must be conducted in the same manner as a school administrative unit audit in 6 
accordance with chapter 221, subchapter 2.  7 
§3805.  Application for and approval of a school management and leadership center  8 
1.  Application.  The commissioner shall establish an application process under this 9 
chapter for the formation of a school management and leadership center.  Th e application 10 
must be in a form and contain such information as required by the commissioner, 11 
including, but not limited to:  12 
A.  The identification of the school administrative units that are applying to form the 13 
school management and leadership center;  14 
B.  The specified structure and governance of the school management and leadership 15 
center and its purposes, functions, programs and services;  16 
C.  How any savings resulting from the formation of the school management and 17 
leadership center will be used; and  18 
D.  A copy of the proposed interlocal agreement pursuant to section 3801, subsection 19 
3. 20 
2.  Commissioner’s approval.  If an application under this section contains the 21 
information required pursuant to subsection 1, the commissioner shall notify each school 22 
administrative unit participating in the school management and leadership center that, 23 
pending voter approval as set forth in subsection 3, the school management and 24 
leadership center is approved pursuant to this chapter. The commissioner shall keep a 25 
regis ter of school management and leadership centers that have been approved pursuant 26 
to this chapter.  27 
3.  Voter approval.  If the commissioner approves an application for a school 28 
management and leadership center pursuant to subsection 2, the school management  and 29 
leadership center must receive voter approval using the process specified in the interlocal 30 
agreement pursuant to section 3801, subsection 3, paragraph B, subparagraph (1).  31 
§3806.  Direct state funding of a school management and leadership center  32 
A sc hool management and leadership center receives direct state funds for start -up 33 
costs in accordance with section 15689, subsection 9.  A school management and 34 
leadership center that provides to members at least 2 different services covering a total of 35 
at least 2 different categories as specified in section 15683 -C, subsection 2 must receive 36 
annual support for 55% of the executive director’s salary and benefits, an accounting and 37 
payroll system and a student information system.  38 
The school administrative units  that are members of a school management and 39 
leadership center must receive state funds in accordance with section 15683 -C. 40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 713 - 128LR2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §3807.  Regional school leadership academies  1 
A regional school leadership academy is a professional development consortium that 2 
comb ines state and local programs and resources, including the preparation, licensure, 3 
certification, professional development and training for educational leadership, into a 4 
coherent system that can significantly improve the recruitment and preparation of 5 
prospective candidates for school principals and other school leadership positions, as well 6 
as the induction, mentoring and retention of principals and school leaders during the first 7 
2 years of employment in their school leadership positions.  The mission of  an academy 8 
may be to enhance the quality of the preservice and in -service staff training programs for 9 
school principals and other school leadership positions, to improve the distribution, 10 
supply and quality of school leadership personnel in underserved sc hool administrative 11 
units in the State and to develop appropriate professional development pathways at 12 
participating schools in the academy.  To fulfill its mission, the academy may work in 13 
coordination with educational leadership mentors and coaches, with  high-performing 14 
educational leaders and with educator preparation programs and statewide education 15 
associations.  16 
Sec. VVVVV -7.  20-A MRSA §5205, sub -§6-B is enacted to read:  17 
6-B.  School management and leadership center enrollment policies.  Members in 18 
a school management and leadership center, as defined in section 3801, subsection 1, 19 
paragraph B, may adopt a mutual policy allowing the transfer of students, with parental 20 
approval, among the member school administrative units. The mutual policy must set 21 
forth procedures and standards governing the transfers, including but not limited to the 22 
school year or years in which the policy applies, application procedures and standards of 23 
responsibility for transportation and special education. Each member school boa rd that 24 
adopts the mutual policy under this subsection shall post a copy of the mutual policy on 25 
the school administrative unit’s publicly accessible website and shall provide timely 26 
notice of the policy to residents of the school administrative unit gover ned by that school 27 
board. For the purposes of chapter 606 -B, a student transferred under this subsection is 28 
considered a resident of the school administrative unit to which the student transferred.  29 
Sec. VVVVV -8.  20-A MRSA §6202, sub -§1-A, as amended by PL  2009, c. 30 
154, §3, is further amended to read:  31 
1-A.  Interpretation.   The statewide assessment program results may be interpreted 32 
in a manner that takes into account the particular role within a school administrative unit 33 
of regional special education or r egional alternative education programs or schools 34 
approved by the commissioner in accordance with chapter 113 -A or  section 7253.  For 35 
these programs or schools, the results may be interpreted by assigning the student and the 36 
scores of the student to the sc hool in the community where the student resides.  The 37 
commissioner shall adopt rules to implement this subsection.  Rules adopted pursuant to 38 
this subsection are routine technical rules as defined in Title 5, chapter 375, subchapter 39 
2-A. 40 
Sec. VVVVV -9.  20-A MRSA §15672, sub -§2-A, ¶B, as amended by PL 2007, 41 
c. 111, §3, is further amended to read:  42 
B.  Lease costs for school buildings when the leases, including leases under which the 43 
school administrative unit may apply the lease payments to the purchase of po rtable, 44 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 714 - 128LR 2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  temporary classroom space, have been approved by the commissioner for the year 1 
prior to the allocation year.  Lease costs include costs for leasing:  2 
(1)  Administrative space.  A school administrative unit engaged in a state - 3 
approved lease -purchase  agreement for administrative space is eligible for state 4 
support until July 1, 2008;  5 
(2)  Temporary and interim instructional space.  Temporary space is instructional 6 
space consisting of one or more mobile or modular buildings that are portable, 7 
that are constructed on - or off -site and that can be disassembled and moved 8 
economically to a new location.  Interim instructional space is fixed instructional 9 
space that a school administrative unit rents for a defined period of time and then 10 
vacates at the end of  the lease.  11 
(a)  A school administrative unit with state -approved need for instructional 12 
space may lease temporary or interim space, with state support, for a 13 
maximum of 5 years.  A school administrative unit may appeal to the 14 
commissioner if this limitati on presents an undue burden.  When making a 15 
determination on a school administrative unit's request for relief based on 16 
undue burden, the commissioner may consider, but is not limited to 17 
considering, the following:  18 
(i)  Fiscal capacity;  19 
(ii)  Enrollment de mographics; and  20 
(iii)  Unforeseen circumstances not within the control of the appealing 21 
school administrative unit.  22 
An extension granted by the commissioner beyond the 5 -year maximum for 23 
state support is limited to a period of one year.  Any additional req uest for 24 
extensions must be submitted and reviewed on an annual basis.  The 25 
commissioner's decision is final.  26 
(b)  A school administrative unit with state -approved need for instructional 27 
space may engage in a lease -purchase agreement for temporary or inter im 28 
instructional space with state support for a maximum of 5 years; and 29 
(3)  Permanent small instructional space that replaces existing approved leased 30 
temporary or interim instructional space.  Permanent small instructional space 31 
consists of new buildings  or additions to existing buildings that are secured to a 32 
permanent foundation.  Once an existing leased temporary or interim 33 
instructional space has been replaced by a permanent small instructional space 34 
through an approved financing agreement, that space  is eligible for state support 35 
for a maximum of 10 years .; and  36 
(4)  Regional programs and services space. A school administrative unit engaged 37 
in a state -approved lease -purchase agreement for regional programs and services 38 
space that serves students from 2  or more school administrative units is eligible 39 
for state support for a maximum of 5 years.  40

 Page 715 - 128LR2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  The department shall adopt rules necessary to implement this paragraph.  Rules 1 
adopted by the department to implement this paragraph are major substantive rules 2 
pursuant to Title 5, chapter 375, subchapter 2 -A; and  3 
Sec. VVVVV -10.  20-A MRSA §15683 -C is enacted to read:  4 
§15683 -C.  School management and leadership center members; calculation of 5 
school management and leadership center administration allocation and 6 
state contribution  7 
Beginning with fiscal year 2018 -19, this section applies to school administrative units 8 
that are members of school management and leadership centers pursuant to chapter 123.  9 
1.  Calculation of school management and leadership center per -pupi l rate.  The 10 
commissioner shall calculate a per -pupil amount for school management and leadership 11 
center administration.  The per -pupil amount for school management and leadership 12 
center administration is based on the actual General Fund expenditures for s chool 13 
administrative units with 2,500 students or more for the functions of school boards, 14 
elections and central offices, as defined in the State's accounting handbook for local 15 
school systems for the most recent year available, excluding expenditures for 16 
administrative technology -related software and less miscellaneous revenues from other 17 
local governments, divided by the average of October and April enrollment counts for 18 
that fiscal year and adjusted by appropriate trends in the Consumer Price Index or ot her 19 
comparable index.  20 
2.  Categories of services of school management and leadership center.  The 21 
following are the categories of services that a school administrative unit that is a member 22 
of a school management and leadership center pursuant to chapter 1 23 may purchase for 23 
funding purposes under section 3806.  24 
A.  Category 1, instructional services, includes the following services:  25 
(1)  Special education programs and administration;  26 
(2)  Gifted and talented programs and administration;  27 
(3)  Alternative edu cation programs and administration;  28 
(4)  Shared educational programs or staff; and  29 
(5)  Educational programs such as summer school, extended school year, 30 
tutoring, advanced placement and other programs that serve students and improve 31 
student achievement.  32 
B.  Category 2, education support services, includes the following services:  33 
(1)  Substitute teachers and staff augmentation;  34 
(2)  Technology and technology support;  35 
(3)  Staff training and professional development;  36 
(4)  Regional school leadership academies ; 37 
(5)  Shared support services programs; and  38 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 716 - 128LR 2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (6)  Shared extracurricular or cocurricular programs.  1 
C.  Category 3, central office services, includes the following services:  2 
(1)  Accounting, payroll, financial management services and procurement;  3 
(2)  Repor ting functions;  4 
(3)  Food service planning and purchasing; and  5 
(4)  Superintendent services.  6 
D.  Category 4, facilities and transportation system services, includes the following 7 
services:  8 
(1)  Transportation, transportation routing and vehicle maintenance ; and  9 
(2)  Energy management and facilities maintenance.  10 
3.  Eligibility for school management and leadership center allocation.  The 11 
commissioner shall determine that a school administrative unit is eligible for a school 12 
management and leadership center a llocation if according to its school management and 13 
leadership center interlocal agreement pursuant to section 3801, subsection 3, the school 14 
administrative unit purchases at least 2 different services covering a total of at least 2 15 
different categories fr om the school management and leadership center as specified in 16 
subsection 2.  17 
4.  Total allocation and state contribution.  The commissioner shall determine an 18 
eligible school administrative unit's total school management and leadership center 19 
allocation un der subsection 3 as the school management and leadership center per -pupil 20 
rate in subsection 1 multiplied by the school administrative unit's subsidizable pupil count 21 
for October 1st of the most recent calendar year prior to the year of funding.  The state  22 
contribution for each school administrative unit's school management and leadership 23 
center allocation is the allocation multiplied by the school administrative unit's state share 24 
percentage pursuant to section 15672, subsection 31, not to exceed 70% and n ot less than 25 
30%.  26

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  PART MMMMMM  1 
Sec. MMMMMM -1.  Criteria for opioid health home grant providers.  By 2 
October 1, 2017, the Department of Health and Human Services, referred to in this Part as 3 
"the depar tment," shall undertake a process to update the criteria for providers included in 4 
a request for proposals for an opioid health home grant.  A grant must provide evidence - 5 
based integrated medication -assisted treatment for patients with opioid use disorder,  6 
when such services are provided by:  7 
1.  Primary care medical provider practices designated as patient -centered medical 8 
homes; or  9 
2.  Behavioral health agencies licensed by the Department of Health and Human 10 
Services.  11 
The department shall establish by emer gency rule pursuant to section 5 of this Part 12 
the revised criteria for qualification as an opioid health home and the amount of the grant 13 
provided to each qualified opioid health home.  14 
Sec. MMMMMM -2.  Funding.  The funding included in Part A for this Part 15 
covers intensive outpatient treatment, intermediate treatment and long -term levels of care, 16 
which include screening, medication, behavioral health counseling and office visits for 17 
patients diagnosed with opioid use disorder.  18 
Sec. MMMMMM -3.  Funds may not b e transferred.  Notwithstanding the 19 
Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 1585 or any other provision of law, funding 20 
provided in Part A for this Part may not be transferred to any other appropriation or 21 
subdivision of an appropriation made by the Legis lature.  22 
Sec. MMMMMM -4.  Funds may not lapse.  Notwithstanding the Maine 23 
Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 1589 or any other provision of law, any unencumbered 24 
balance of appropriations contained in Part A for this Part remaining at the end of fiscal 25 
year 2017 -18 and fiscal year 2018 -19 may not lapse but must be carried forward to be 26 
used for the same purposes.  27 
Sec. MMMMMM -5.  Emergency rule -making authority.  The Department of 28 
Health and Human Services is authorized to adopt emergency rules under the Maine  29 
Revised Statutes, Title 5, sections 8054 and 8073 as necessary to implement the 30 
provisions of this Part without the necessity of demonstrating that immediate adoption is 31 
necessary to avoid a threat to public health, safety or general welfare.  32

Sec. OOOOOO -1.  Departmentwide structure and operations review.  The 4 
Commissioner of Health and Human Services shall analyze the structures and functions 5 
of the Department of Health and Human Services and identify potential savings in the 6 
2018 -2019 biennial budget. The savings identified must provide a minimum of 7 
$30,000,0 00 in General Fund savings in fiscal year 2018 -19. 8 
Sec. OOOOOO -2.  Report.  The Commissioner of Health and Human Services 9 
shall submit a report of the commissioner's findings and recommendations under this Part 10 
to the Joint Standing Committee on Appropriat ions and Financial Affairs by September 11 
30, 2017.  The report must include the findings and recommendations pursuant to section 12 
1 and any necessary implementing legislation.  The Joint Standing Committee on 13 
Appropriations and Financial Affairs is authorize d to submit legislation related to the 14 
report to the Second Regular Session of the 128th Legislature to distribute the amount of 15 
savings deappropriated in section 4 of this Part.  16 
Sec. OOOOOO -3.  Transfer - Contingent.  If, after receipt and review of the 17 
recommendations presented by the Commissioner of Health and Human Services 18 
pursuant to section 2, the Legislature fails to enact legislation by the conclusion of the 19 
Second Regular Session of the 128th Legislature that offsets and distributes the 20 
$30,000,00 0 in savings deappropriated in section 4 of this Part, the State Budget Officer 21 
shall transfer the $30,000,000 deappropriated in section 4 by financial order from the 22 
Departmentwide 0640 program to the Medical Care - Payments to Providers program 23 
upon appr oval of the Governor. This transfer is considered an adjustment to 24 
appropriations in fiscal year 2018 -19. 25

Sec. PPPPPP -1.  12 MRSA §1802, as amended by PL 2007, c. 240, Pt. NN, §1; 2 
PL 2011, c. 657, Pt. W, §§5 and 7; and PL 2013, c. 405, Pt. A, §24, is further amended to 3 
read:  4 
§1802.  Bureau of Parks and Lands established  5 
There is established within th e Department of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry 6 
the Bureau of Parks and Lands, which shall carry out the responsibilities of State 7 
Government relating to parks, historic sites, submerged and intertidal lands, public 8 
reserved lands and nonreserved pu blic lands.  The bureau shall also carry out all the 9 
duties relating to recreation, the Allagash Wilderness Waterway, the Snowmobile Trail 10 
Fund, public facilities for boats, the ATV Recreational Management Fund, the Maine 11 
Trails System, the Maine Conservat ion Corps, the State Environmental Resource 12 
Volunteer Effort Program and any other responsibilities of the former Bureau of Parks 13 
and Recreation, Bureau of Public Lands and Maine State Park and Recreation 14 
Commission.  15 
The executive head of the bureau is the  director.  The director is assisted in executive 16 
duties by a deputy director.  The director and the deputy director shall attend personally 17 
to the duties of their offices as far as practicable.  The director and the deputy director are 18 
appointed by and se rve at the pleasure of the commissioner.  19 
1.  Director.  The executive head of the bureau is the director.  20 
A.  The powers and duties of the position of director may not be combined with any 21 
other position within the bureau or department.  22 
B.  The position of  director may not be filled in an acting capacity; the appointee 23 
must be a permanent full -time employee.  24 
2.  Deputy director.  The director is assisted in executive duties by a deputy director.  25 
3.  Personal attendance to duties.  The director and the deput y director shall attend 26 
personally to the duties of their offices as far as practicable.  27 
4.  Appointment.  The director and the deputy director are appointed by and serve at 28 
the pleasure of the commissioner.  29

2019.  Beginning the pay week commencing closest to January 1, 2019, the salary 27 
schedules, grades an d stipends for the Judicial Department employees in the 28 
administrative services bargaining unit, the supervisory services bargaining unit, the law 29 
enforcement bargaining unit and the professional services bargaining unit must be 30

agreements ratified prior to September 30, 2017.  33

pursuant to the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 26, section 1282, subsection 5, paragraphs 36

that given employees covered by the collective bargaining agreements.  38

SUMMARY  17 
PART A  18 
 19 
This Part makes appropriations and allocations of funds for the 2018 -2019 biennium.  20 
PART B  21 
 22 
This Part makes appropriations and allocations of funds for approved reclassifications 23 
and range changes.  24 
PART C  25 
 26 
This Part does the following.  27 
1.  It establishes the total cost of education from kindergarten to grade 12 for fiscal 28 
year 2017 -18, the state contribution and the annual target for the state share percentage.  29 
2.  It provides statutory changes to the Essential Programs and Services Funding Act 30 
for implementation in the 2017 -2018 school year.  31 
3.  It provides statutory changes to the Essen tial Programs and Services Funding Act 32 
for implementation in the 2018 -2019 school year.  33 
4.  It provides statutory changes for the funding and oversight of the Maine School 34 
for Marine Science, Technology, Transportation and Engineering.  35 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 726 - 128LR 2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  5.  It directs the C ommissioner of Education to develop a plan for funding gifted and 1 
talented education and certain miscellaneous allocations, and to review the per -pupil 2 
allocation for system administration.  3 
6.  It sets the effective dates for certain sections of this Part.  4 
PART N  5 
 6 
This Part makes the following changes to the laws governing the Consensus 7 
Economic Forecasting Commission.  8 
1.  It allows the terms of commission members to be staggered.  9 
2.  It changes reporting requirements to conform to current practice.  10 
3.  It changes the required number of meetings of the commission and the Revenue 11 
Forecasting Committee from 4 a year to 3.  12 
PART O  13 
 14 
This Part transfers responsibility for the supervision and administrative control of risk 15 
management insurance, claims and loss cont rol for the State from the Director of the 16 
Bureau of General Services and the Bureau of General Services to the State Controller 17 
and the Office of the State Controller.  18 
This Part also provides that the risk management division assists the State Controller 19 
in carrying out these duties and that the division is transferred from the Bureau of General 20 
Services to the Office of the State Controller.  21 
PART Q  22 
 23 
This Part directs the Revisor of Statutes, when updating the Maine Revised Statutes, 24 
to change the name of the "displaced homemaker program" to the "New Ventures Maine 25 
program" and the name of the "Displaced Homemakers Advisory Council" to the "New 26 
Ventures Maine Advisory Council."  This Part also changes the name of the Maine 27 
Centers for Women, Work and Commun ity program to the New Ventures Maine program 28 
to reflect the name currently used by the University of Maine System.  29 
PART S  30 
 31 
This Part continues authorization for each individual tax expenditure provided by 32 
statute.  33 
PART T  34 
 35 
This Part authorizes the State Ta x Assessor to implement a training program to 36 
develop the expertise of revenue agents and property appraisers.  Upon successful 37 
completion of the program and demonstration of prescribed competencies, employees in 38 
these classifications may immediately progr ess to the senior position in the respective 39 
classification series.  40 
PART V  41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 727 - 128LR2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT   1 
This Part establishes that the base assessment limit for the provision of correctional 2 
services in a county budget may not be less than the limit established by law.  The Part 3 
clarifies that the base assessment limit that carries forward from one year to the next is 4 
the amount collected by the county for the provision of correctional services in the prior 5 
year.  6 
PART X  7 
 8

biennium for judicial branch and executive branch departments and agencies and removes 10 
the attrition requirement for the District Attorneys Salaries program for the 2018 -2019 11 
biennium.  This Part also requires the State Budget Officer to sub mit a report of the 12 
savings calculations and transfers to the Joint Standing Committee on Appropriations and 13 
Financial Affairs by September 1, 2018.  14

PART XXXX  3 
 4 
This Part increases compensation of active retired judges and justices of the state 5 
courts from $300 per day to $350 per day and from $175 per 1/2 day to $200 pe r 1/2 day.  6 
This Part also provides for a raise of 3% for judges and justices of the state courts for 7 
both fiscal year 2017 -18 and fiscal year 2018 -19. 8 
PART YYYY  9 
 10 
This Part clarifies that the record search fee schedule established by the State Court 11 
Adminis trator is for those record searches performed by Judicial Department employees 12 
and specifies that the record search fees deposited into the fund for use by the State Court 13 
Administrator to fund publications, forms and information technology are those fees for 14 
record searches performed by Judicial Department employees.  15 
This Part also allows the Supreme Judicial Court to raise or establish fees on online 16 
electronic case searches performed by Judicial Department employees, document delivery 17 
and case filings an d surcharges on fines for the purpose of paying the cost of maintaining 18 
an electronic filing and court information management system.  19 
PART ZZZZ  20 
 21 
This Part provides that the members of the Maine Unemployment Insurance 22 
Commission must be sworn and may be rem oved by the Governor for inefficiency, 23 
willful neglect of duty or malfeasance in office, but only with the review and concurrence 24 
of the joint standing committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over labor matters 25 
upon hearing in executive session or  by impeachment. Before removing a commission 26 
member, the Governor shall notify the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the 27 
House of Representatives of the removal and the reasons for the removal.  28 
PART AAAAA  29 
 30 
This Part moves the original jurisdictio n of employer unemployment appeals cases 31 
from the Maine Unemployment Insurance Commission, the members of which are 32 
appointed by the Governor, to the Department of Labor, Bureau of Unemployment 33 
Compensation, Division of Administrative Hearings to conform w ith federal law.  34 
This Part also revises the law to comply with Section 303(a)(3) of the federal Social 35 
Security Act, which requires that the first level of appeals hearings must be conducted by 36 
a merit -staffed governmental employee in order to meet the imp artial hearing requirement 37 
of Section 303(a)(3). For the purposes of this provision, "merit -staffed" means that the 38 
individuals are subject to personnel standards based on a merit system and are not 39 
political appointees.  40 
PART BBBBB  41 
 42 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 736 - 128LR 2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  This Part repeals the p rovision of law that prohibits any unencumbered balance in the 1 
Competitive Skills Scholarship Fund from being used for a different purpose without 2 
legislative approval.  3 
PART CCCCC  4 
 5 
Section 1 of this Part changes the weekly benefit subtraction factor for pa rtial 6 
unemployment, referred to as the residual amount, from $25 to $100 to incentivize 7 
reemployment and connection to the workforce.  This amendment requires that the 8 
residual amount must be increased by the increase, if any, in the cost of living as 9 
meas ured by the percentage increase, if any, as of August of the previous year over the 10 
level as of August of the year preceding that year in the Consumer Price Index for Urban 11 
Wage Earners and Clerical Workers, CPI -W, for the Northeast Region, or its successo r 12 
index, as published by the United States Department of Labor, Bureau of Labor Statistics 13 
or its successor agency.  14 
The remainder of this Part changes the experience rating and the lowest tax schedule 15 
to make Maine unemployment tax rates more equitable. Th e chargeability of benefit 16 
charges is revenue neutral.  17 
PART EEEEE  18 
 19 
This Part establishes new surcharges on licenses issued by the Department of Marine 20 
Resources and directs the new surcharges to the Coastal Fisheries Research, Management 21 
and Enforcement Fu nd, Other Special Revenue Funds account established in the 22 
department. The fund must be used to fund scientific research, management and 23 
enforcement activities related to marine resources.  24 
PART FFFFF  25 
 26 
This Part renames the Board of Registration for Profess ional Engineers program 27 
within the Department of Professional and Financial Regulation the State Board of 28 
Licensure for Professional Engineers program.  29 
PART IIIII  30 
 31 
This Part provides that the Executive Director of the Gambling Control Unit has the 32 
authorit y to administer and enforce the provisions of the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 33 
17, chapter 13 -A governing the conduct of beano and Title 17, chapter 62 governing 34 
games of chance.  35 
PART JJJJJ  36 
 37 
This Part transfers the oversight, administration and enforcemen t of the Maine 38 
Revised Statutes, Title 17, chapter 13 -A governing beano from the Chief of the State 39 
Police to the Gambling Control Unit within the Department of Public Safety.  It reduces 40 
some requirements for organizations that conduct beano, such as requ iring them to 41 
register with the Gambling Control Unit rather than apply for a license and to maintain 42 
records of the use of proceeds from beano rather than regularly file disposition of funds 43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 281, L.D. 390  
 
 Page 737 - 128LR2175(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  reports with the Gambling Control Unit.  High -stakes beano under  Title 17, chapter 13 -A 1 
is still subject to licensure.  This Part also adds some provisions to Title 17, chapter 13 -A 2 
to permit schools, campgrounds and resorts to conduct beano for the entertainment of 3 
their guests, including children under 16 years of ag e, as long as certain requirements are 4 
met. 5 
PART KKKKK  6 
 7 
This Part transfers in the Department of Public Safety the oversight, administration 8 
and enforcement of the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 17, chapter 62 governing games of 9 
chance from a licensing unit  to the Gambling Control Unit.  It reduces some requirements 10 
for organizations that conduct certain games of chance, such as requiring them to register 11 
with the Gambling Control Unit rather than apply for a license and maintaining records of 12 
the use of pro ceeds from games rather than regularly filing disposition of funds reports 13 
with the Gambling Control Unit.  Card games and most tournament games are still 14 
subject to licensure under this Part.  It adds a provision that permits the operation of 15 
cribbage tou rnaments for charitable purposes without a license.  These tournaments are 16 
not required to be conducted by a nonprofit organization and may be conducted in places 17 
like a restaurant or brewery tap room.  Entry fees are limited to $25, and all fees must be 18 
paid as prizes or donated to a verifiable charitable purpose.  It also makes changes 19 
regarding the conduct of raffles for charitable purposes, including a provision that permits 20 
the conduct of a raffle with a prize value up to $1,000 to be conducted by a pe rson or 21 
organization without having to be licensed by or registered with the Gambling Control 22 
Unit.  23 
PART LLLLL  24 
 25 
This Part provides that public safety inspectors in the Department of Public Safety, 26 
Office of the State Fire Marshal for the purpose of enforci ng the Maine Revised Statutes, 27 
Title 25, section 2452, relating to statewide enforcement powers of the National Fire 28 
Protection Association No. 101, Life Safety Code, have the right to execute or serve 29 
criminal and civil violation process against offenders  who violate the National Fire 30 
Protection Association No. 101, Life Safety Code.  31 
PART MMMMM  32 
 33 
This Part amends the law regarding examinations of plans for construction, 34 
reconstruction or repairs submitted to the Department of Public Safety by establishing a  35 
single fee schedule for new construction, reconstruction, repairs and renovations of 1.5/10 36 
of 1% of the cost to construct or reconstruct the portion of the project subject to State Fire 37 
Marshal review.  38

 7

PART VVVVV  9 
 10 
This Part provides for the creation of 9 to 12 school management and leadership 11 
centers. School administrative units may voluntarily establish a school management and 12 
leadership center through an in terlocal agreement and may include associate members 13 
through contractual agreements or memoranda of understanding.  A school management 14 
and leadership center provides administrative and education functions in accordance with 15 
the interlocal agreement and fu nctions as an extension of the schools that are members of 16 
the school management and leadership center.  Participating school administrative units 17 
voluntarily choose which educational functions or support services they purchase from a 18 
school management and  leadership center.  19 
PART LLLLLL  20 
 21

adjust the fees for testing weighing and measuring devices so as to generate additional 23 
undedicated revenue to the General Fund of $100,000 ann ually, beginning in fiscal year 24 
2017 -18. 25 
PART MMMMMM  26 
 27 
This Part updates the criteria for service providers included in a request for proposals 28 
for an opioid health home grant and identifies the services to be provided to individuals 29 
who have been diagnosed  with opioid use disorder.  Additionally, this Part establishes 30 
that the funds provided are not to be transferred and may not lapse at the end of the 31 
current fiscal year.  Finally, this Part authorizes the Department of Health and Human 32 
Services to adopt e mergency rules as necessary to implement the provisions of this Part 33 
without the necessity of demonstrating that immediate adoption is necessary to avoid a 34 
threat to public health, safety or general welfare.  35 
PART NNNNNN  36 
 37

to the Maine Clean Election Fund by June 1, 2018.  This transfer is scheduled in statute 39 
but needs to occur earlier than scheduled in order to ensure that adequate funds will be 40 
available to the Commission on Governmental Ethics and Election Practices.  41

deappropriation from the Departmentwide 0640 program will be transferred by financial 13 
order to the Medical Care - Payments to Providers 0147 program upon approval of the 14 
Governor.  15 
PART PPPPPP  16 
 17

Lands within the Department of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry to specify that 19 
the duties of the position may not be combined with any other position within the bureau 20 
or department and that the position may not be filled in an acting capacity.  21

 23

chapter 368, Part LLLL, section 2.  26

Human Services adopted new eligibility rules in 2016.  32
